DISS_description.DISS_title: College Bound Type Programs and Post-secondary Enrollment for Broward County Public Schools Students from Economically Challenged Communities

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: achievement gap, African American, Black Hispanic and low-income, college pathway programs, college type programs, post-secondary enrollment

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There are widespread concerns about disparities in educational attainment in the United States. Unfortunately African American, Hispanic, Native American, and low-income Broward County Public Schools high school students participate in College Bound Type Programs at lower rates than students of other races and ethnicities. Many of these students are missing out on the significant advantages associated with college pathway programs such as higher post-secondary enrollment, persistence, and graduation rates. This quantitative outcomes study examined the associations with post-secondary enrollment of participating in College Bound Type Programs for Black and Hispanic Broward County Public Schools students who attended high schools in low-income communities. 3,620 students who entered ninth grade in 2013 were studied through graduation. Univariate, bivariate, and logistic regression analysis were utilized. Participation in College Bound Type Programs were found to be positively associated with post-secondary enrollment and 4-year college post-secondary enrollment respectively. These results highlight the positive outcomes associated with College Bound Type Program participation for this population. Policy makers and educators are urged to work together to start preparing parents and students as early as elementary school in preparation for College Bound Type Programs in high school.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Trauma-Informed Care in Florida Child Care Centers

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: adverse childhood experiences, child care, early childhood, florida, trauma, trauma informed care

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There has been an increased interest in trauma-informed care practices in Florida to support children and families across the state who are currently dealing with trauma effects (Florida Department of Children and Families [DCF], 2019). My study sought to understand better the multiple experiences of child care center directors implementing trauma informed care practices after completing the Department's approved TICD course. The trauma-informed care 40-hour course for center directors was launched in 2019 and has been completed by more than 850 child care center directors throughout the state of Florida. I conducted a qualitative multi-site case study using the implementation model. As for sampling, I used a two-tier sampling structure: convenience and critical-case. I conducted one-on-one remote in-depth interviews with 11 child care directors in Miami-Dade County currently implementing trauma-informed care practices. The analytic approach was based on Creswell's Spiral, allowing me to review data multiple times while processing (Creswell, 2013). Overall, directors shared their willingness to assist at-risk children and families in their serving area by helping children cope with their ACEs. The findings are here presented by research question as follows: TICP strategies, directors’ challenges, and children behavior. As a result of the study, several recommendations were made to the Florida Department of Children and Families, Child Care Policy Administration, child care practitioners implementing trauma-informed care, and future researchers of this problem of practice.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Asymptotics of Certain Short-Range Interactions on Rectifiable Sets and Beyond

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Energy and Polarization, Fractal Geometry, Geometric Measure Theory, Packing and Covering, Potential Theory, Renewal Theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: We study the asymptotics of various short-range interactions, namely, minimal Riesz $s$-energy, maximal Riesz $s$-polarization, best packing, and best covering, on sets satisfying minimal smoothness assumptions. In particular, we present the proof of the Poppy-Seed Bagel Theorem for polarization and covering on $(\mathcal{H}_d,d)$-rectifiable subsets of Euclidean space with like Hausdorff measure and Minkowski content. This represents the sealing of a gap in the generality of results that existed between energy and polarization. In practice, we verify the short-range properties of polarization and covering to deduce the first order asymptotic formulas for these quantities, depending in a universal fashion upon $\mathcal{H}_d(A)$. We simultaneously use the short range properties to deduce weak* uniformity of optima in the large configuration limit. Our results are sharp in the following sense: for sets lacking one of the regularity assumptions mentioned above, asymptotics do not depend on $\mathcal{H}_d(A)$ in the same way as stated there. \par The manuscript contains several of our results concerning asymptotics of short-range interactions on metrically separated self-similar fractals. Our primary result is the convergence of hyper-singular polarization on independent fractals. We further detail the proofs of convergence of minimal $s$-energy on lattice fractals along explicit subsequences, and the general non-existence of asymptotics for packing and covering on these sets. Taken with results of Lalley, the negative results provide a characterization of convergence for packing and covering on a given self-similar fractal in terms of the algebraic relationship between its contraction ratios. From the negative results, we also derive non-existence of asymptotics for energy and polarization, for sufficiently large parameter. \par Finally, we discuss some open problems concerning short-range interactions. We draw upon results of Falconer, Gatzouras, and Lapidus to conjecture about the universality of asymptotic formulas for packing and covering on some Minkowski measurable subsets of $\mathbb{R}$ with non-integer Minkowski dimension $d\in(0,1).$ Then, we view the Riesz $s$-energy of $N$-point configurations as a function of $N$ points in Euclidean space, and propose a rigorous study of the dynamics of gradient descent as a means of producing \textit{local} minima of Riesz $s$-energy on spheres. This leads us to conjecture that "bad" starting configurations make up a negligible proportion of all configurations with respect to $N$-fold surface measure.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MONOMER- AND POLYMER-BASED N-HETEROCYCLIC CARBENE COATING OF TRANSITION METAL CORE NANOCOLLOIDS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The unique size-dependent optical and physical properties of inorganic nanocrystals such as those made of metals and semiconductors have generated an enormous interest in exploiting them to develop a variety of applications. Due to their unique features, they have also been integrated into a variety of applications, including biological sensing, imaging, optoelectronic devices, and as fluorescent probes in biology. Growth of these materials using either hydrophilic or hydrophobic conditions yields nanocolloids that are not readily compatible with biological systems, due to either the hydrophobic nature of the ligands or the labile properties of the coatings. The main focus of this dissertation is to design and synthesis a series of molecular scale and multidentate N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-based ligands and apply them for the surface functionalization various inorganic nanocrystals and render them water soluble. We also summarize coordination interactions of NHC moieties with the gold surfaces to get better understanding about nature of NHC-Au bond. In Chapter 1, we summarize some of the basic optical and physical properties of inorganic nanomaterials including, quantum dots (QDs), gold nanoparticles (AuNPs), and gold nanoclusters (AuNCs). We briefly describe the history of growth strategies for preparing high quality QDs, AuNPs, and AuNCs. We then provide an overview of the surface functionalization methods to assemble colloidally stable and biocompatible nanoparticles followed by introducing the N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-based ligands as a novel metal anchoring group and their application in modern surface chemistry. In Chapter 2, we will focus on the synthesis of hydrophobic oleylamine-coated gold nanoparticles (OLA-AuNPs) and the surface coordination with N-Heterocyclic Carbenes (NHCs) relying on ligand substitution strategy. We detail the synthesis and characterization of three distinct water-compatible NHC-based ligands: an amine-modified small molecule, a monomeric NHC appended with a short poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) block, and a modified poly(isobutylene-alt-maleic anhydride), PIMA, that simultaneously presents multiple NHC groups and several short PEG chains. We find that rapid competitive ligation onto the AuNPs (often requiring several minutes of mixing) takes place regardless of the exact structure of the ligand. Furthermore, the long-term colloidal stability of the NHC-stabilized AuNPs have been tested after phase transfer to water, a highly challenging chemical venue for such groups due to their moisture sensitive nature. Our experimental data show that the multidentate NHC polymer coating exhibits the highest affinity to AuNPs, which manifests in long-term colloidal stability in buffer media, absence of any aggregation or degradation build up for at least one year of storage. In addition, the NHC-polymer-coated AuNPs exhibit long term resistance to competition from reducing small molecules such as dithiothreitol, DTT. In Chapter 3, we introduce a top-down etching strategy using poly (ethylene glycol)-appended-NHC (PEG-NHC) ligands to promote surface digestion of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). We find that under long term incubation conditions using excess molar ratios of PEG-NHC ligands, with respect to AuNPs, progressive etching of Au surfaces takes place. This progressively alters the plasmon absorption features, yielding the formation of NHC-Au complexes. This top-down etching method has provided us insights about the nature and strength of coordination interactions of NHC groups with Au surfaces; these interactions are inherent controlled by the σ-donating nature (soft Lewis base) of NHC which match the soft acidic nature of Au surfaces, resulting in very strong coordination interactions and binding. We use UV-vis absorption measurements to monitor the transformation process, where loss of plasmonic features of AuNPs with time takes place. We further characterize the digestion kinetics by extracting a characteristic time which is found to depend among others on the ligand to AuNP molar excess. We then combine these data with 2-D 1H, 13C NMR spectroscopy, matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI), and transmission electron microscopy measurements to identify the structure and chemical nature of the resulting NHC-PEG-Au complexes. In Chapter 4, we describe the formation of fluorescent blue emitting ultrasmall gold nanoclusters (Au NCs), following the digestion process described in Chapter 3 above, achieved under thermal treatment. This route offers an elegant way to produce stable and homogeneously dispersed AuNCs. Specifically, we show that heating of Au-NHC complexes triggers the formation of ultra-small gold nanoclusters that are fluorescent in the blue region of the optical spectrum upon UV excitation. Here, the starting non-fluorescent NHC-Au(I) complexes undergo aurophilic interactions (as is the tendency for gold(I) compounds) and form blue fluorescent small size nanoclusters. We carry out a thorough characterization of the nanoclusters using analytical techniques such as UV-vis absorption, fluorescence spectroscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. Among others, we find that these nanoclusters show the excitation maximum at 380 nm and the emission maximum at 460 nm. Transmission electron microscopic analysis shows that most of these particles are <1 nm. In Chapter 5, we provide a summary of the work assembled in this dissertation focusing on coordination interactions of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-based ligands with the inorganic nanocrystals, along with the future research directions that expand on the ligation of NHC ligands with other transition metal cores including iron, silver, and platinum nanoparticles and their potential applications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Teacher Perceptions of Beginner-Level Piano Technique and Injury Prevention

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Beginner Piano Lessons, Injury Prevention, Piano Pedagogy, Piano Technique, Playing-Related Musculoskeletal Disorders

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Many studies have been conducted examining musicians’ injuries and their prevention; however, most of this research focuses on the advanced pianist. Pedagogues and researchers agree that the early stages of piano study are crucial for developing proper habits regarding piano technique, and many believe that poor piano technique can be a factor in playing-related injury. An examination of piano teachers’ perceptions and practices regarding beginner-level technique and injury prevention is necessary in order to further investigate and understand the causes and solutions to this medical phenomenon. The purpose of this mixed methods study was to investigate current perspectives and perceptions of pre-college piano teachers regarding teaching technique to the beginner-level student and the relationship those perspectives have with injury prevention. Several factors were examined including the extent these teachers’ strategies reflected existing research concerning injury prevention and technique. Influences such as method books or prior education were also assessed to determine the root source of pedagogical choices. The researcher created a questionnaire that was distributed to pre-college piano teachers from across the United States. A total of 216 participants responded to the survey. The respondents answered questions regarding (I) demographic information; (II) teaching technique perspectives and practices; (III) method book information; and (IV) teaching injury prevention perspectives and practices. Both quantitative and qualitative data were collected. Results suggested that many teachers do believe the relationship between beginner-level technique instruction and injury prevention exists; however, the emphasis each participant places on certain techniques varies across demographic groups. When teachers were divided into groups according to their preferred method books, the order in which they introduced technical skills to students varied. Emphasis on various skills also differed when participants were organized into groups according to their personal experiences with playing-related musculoskeletal disorders. Other demographic groups such as the primary age group taught seemed to have little bearing on the responses. According to a pair of Pearson Correlation Coefficients, weak positive relationships were found to exist between the participants’ awareness of injury prevention and their education level and between their awareness and their amount of teaching experience. A series of open-ended questions allowed for the participating teachers to describe their teaching philosophies and strategies in their own words. Many commented positively on the importance of teaching technique while others detailed tactics they used in teaching students. Some described strategies they used at various stages of learning. A few respondents even reported having no specific philosophies regarding the subject matter. These responses were also compared to existing research literature concerning piano technique. Many mentioned strategies that have been shown to benefit students in the injury prevention area include slow practice, warming up, and teaching students to avoid tension in their playing apparatus. While some stated that they often delay serious technical study until later in the student’s playing career, many comments were made about prioritizing technique in order to prevent playing issues which many researchers have concluded as best practice for piano teachers. The prevalence of body awareness and technique methodology training was also surveyed. A majority (54.41%) of participants reported they had received some sort of training although that education varied from attending a local music teachers workshop to being certified in popular methods such as Alexander Technique or the Taubman Approach. Those who indicated more specific and detailed training often provided meticulous responses concerning their teaching philosophies. The researcher recommends for all beginner-level piano teachers to prioritize healthy piano technique with their students including using the parents of young students as a helpful resource to aid in the child’s development. Teachers who feel inadequately prepared to aid students in this area should seek further education through workshops, books, conferences, and other opportunities to better equip themselves for teaching. This study provides the basis for more research to be conducted on beginner-level piano technique in order to assist in the prevention of future injuries and to promote healthy and fulfilling piano playing.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Student perceptions of and preferences for online instructor course introductions

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Online instructors utilize instructional strategies to mitigate challenges that arise from transactional distance. These strategies can also facilitate establishing instructor social presence and identity, which is a common concern in online learning contexts. Effective online course introductions provide an opportunity for instructors to introduce themselves to online learners and model effective self-disclosures early in the course. Introductions help online learners know more about their course instructors and help them have a sense of what kind of an instructor they will be engaging in learning interactions with.Although course introductions are common first-day-of-the-class activities, there is limited empirical research on what students like to know about their instructors at the start of a course. Furthermore, previous studies demonstrate inconsistent findings regarding student perceptions of and preferences for the timing and type of instructor self-disclosures that are appropriate in an educational context. This exploratory study uses survey design to examine undergraduate and graduate students’ perceptions of and preferences for online instructor course introductions. Participants were recruited from a university’s research pool. The data set included 110 responses that were analyzed using descriptive statistics and content analysis. Findings show that it is important for online learners to know about their instructors, preferably their professional qualifications. When the instructor feels like a real person, students feel like they learn more. Most students turn to multiple different sources to learn more about their instructors even before a class begins. Reading the instructor’s course introduction is the most common approach to learning more about the instructor, while looking up the instructor on social media is the least common approach. Aligned with knowing more about the instructor’s professional qualifications, students find instructor self-disclosures about professional qualifications (e.g., course information, prior professional experience, college experiences, prior education, and hobbies) more appropriate than personal life details (e.g., personal opinions, relationship information, religious affiliation, socio-economic status, political affiliations, and financial information). Course information related disclosures had the highest approval ratings, while financial information had the least. Most students like to know what their online instructors look and sound like. Sharing instructor photos and videos as part of online course introductions had high approval ratings. Participants prefer instructor photo as a professional photo or headshot more than an informal photo or snapshot and a selfie. Moreover, instructor photos related to profession had the highest approval ratings in terms of types of photos that an instructor can add as part of course introduction, followed by pets, travel, family, and food. Introduction videos should be shot in the instructor’s office, followed by in a classroom, in their home, and outdoors. When asked how they perceive an online instructor based on a course introduction with no self-disclosure and with prior professional experiences and hobbies self-disclosures, students perceive the latter as more friendly, approachable, interested in their learning, and interested in the class. Moreover, they reported higher ratings of willingness to email the instructor and visit the instructor in office hour. This finding suggests that appropriate self-disclosures early at the start of a course might help instructors reduce tensions around transactional distance and help them be perceived as real, and increase student willingness to interact with their instructors. The findings of this study challenge instructional practices in which instructors self-disclose personal and vulnerable information early in the course and personal information in general. Overall, this exploratory study provide additional insights to the literature on social presence and identity as well as instructor self-disclosure in online learning contexts. Limitations were presented and implications for theory, research, and practice were discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DATA-DRIVEN DECISION-MAKING PRACTICES: AN EXPLORATORY CASE STUDY OF THE DIVISION OF STUDENT AFFAIRS AT SOUTH COUNTY COLLEGE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Data, Improvement, Student Affairs

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study aimed to address the state of data driven decision practices within the Division of Student Affairs at South County College. Framed by an exploratory qualitative case study, this project conducted semi-structured interviews of directors of student affairs and a document analysis of annual reports of the seven departments that constitute the Division. This exploratory case study set out to investigate how the departments within the Division define data, the practices and use of data, and the challenges that faced when managing data. The results from this study reported that participants defined data by the source’s name, platform’s name or simply the name of the office from where they retrieve the data. Participants also highlighted the important role data plays in their department’s ability to identify and attend to students’ needs. This approach connects with the findings on how student affairs personnel use data, the use of data to make improvement in their services and operations offered to students, and to inform their supervisors, leadership, and the college community about their departments’ accomplishments and advances of their goals. When addressing participants’ challenges on managing data, access to data is the major challenge emphasized by participants. This challenge of accessibility to data is described in two ways: more data access for staff and colleagues; and more communication about data availability. In addition, availability of data training is another challenge identified by participants. When talking about what type of training or data literacy is needed, their perception varies upon their experience and contact with data. Accordingly, this study proposes a series of recommendations to support continuous improvement of data practices within the Division of Student Affairs. These recommendations are: enhance data processes and procedures for data access, expand data literacy training, and improve communication and collaboration among the different colleges’ stakeholders.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE APPLICATION OF VENEZUELAN MARACAS IN WESTERN ART AND CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Errata, Maracas, Notation, Pedagogy, Percussion, Venezuela

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this document is to examine contemporary performance practice of the maracas and how application of specific techniques can prove beneficial to standard orchestral and modern art music forms. There is little extant pedagogy in the field, therefore awareness of recent trends (emphasis on world music in the classical percussion curriculum) will hopefully cultivate new options and ideas concerning interpretation of western notation and performance practice. It is important to understand the instruments themselves—the construction and physics to be sure, but also production and practice. Maracas come in many different forms, so it is essential to illuminate options including mass production versus those made by hand. Perhaps more importantly, a brief overview of traditional Venezuelan music is necessary to connect culture with performance practice. Several genres of Venezuelan music will be discussed as well as the instruments specific to those genres. And finally, this document will provide guidance regarding adaptation of current notation and their application to significant works including maracas.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO PROFESSIONAL AUDITION RECORDINGS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Audio, Camera, Microphone, Music, Recording, Video

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise aims to explore the evolution of pre-screening audition requirements for college music programs and demonstrate best practices for producing professional pre-screening audition recordings for graduate school, competitions, and music festivals. By learning and applying professional audio-video recording skills, students can learn to record their pre-screening recordings for various platforms, providing opportunities for education and performance while emphasizing entrepreneurship and advancement.While all remote audition recordings require video (and audio), the guidelines and technical requirements surrounding the submission process are evolving annually. As students plan and prepare multiple lists of audition repertoire, the importance of the actual recording process is often overlooked. Post-pandemic technological advances in media (specifically audio/video and file transfer/shared media platforms) have provided numerous opportunities to simultaneously capture HD video and high-resolution audio. The first part of this document focuses on university music programs and their pre-screening audition requirements. Chapters 2 and 3 introduce basic audio and video terminology, gear, and recording fundamentals. Chapter 4 features in-depth explanations of how the materials learned in chapters 2 and 3 can be applied to capture pre-screening recordings at the highest level. Chapter 5 contains guiding wisdom and thoughts offered by the author to college music students interested in learning audio-video recording, including starting a recording business, how to find work, and the variety of opportunities available to college music students interested in taking up recording as an additional source of income and/or potential career path. Finally, Part Two contains supplemental advanced audio and video terminology for those interested in further study.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Situated Knowledges in Different World Regions: Reflections on Mosquito Control and Malaria Prevention Knowledge and Curricular Approaches to Bring Diverse Global Knowledges into World Regional Geography

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The primary objective of this dissertation is to scrutinize knowledge production. We recognize the work produced and shared by feminist geographers such as Donna Haraway and Gillian Rose that have asserted systemic biases in how knowledge is produced and reproduced. This work, like others before, will push beyond the ‘vantage point of master subject’ (Haraway 1988) and engage a variety of participants and research methodologies to answer our research questions. In doing so, this dissertation aims to add a mixed methods approach to the growing body of literature to probe the partiality of knowledge (Nightingale 2003). This dissertation utilizes multiple methodologies to conduct research to demonstrate the importance of recognizing the multitude of knowledge sources when conducting research and aims to amplify situated and local knowledge, particularly from the Global South. To date, there remain significant barriers for underrepresented perspectives and voices to reach academia and the published literature (Hedding and Breetzke 2021), for which this dissertation hopes to improve.Malaria remains the world’s deadliest vector-borne disease, resulting in over 200 million human cases and more than 400,000 deaths annually. While some progress has been made in combating malaria, Sumba Island, Indonesia has lagged much of the rest of Indonesia and the region in lowering malaria infections. Chapters 2-3 survey communities of East Sumba Island, Indonesia to understand knowledge, attitudes, and practices of mosquito control and malaria prevention. Chapter 2 employs a qualitative approach to investigate knowledge, attitudes, and practices surrounding mosquito control and prevention methods in East Sumba Regency, Indonesia. While malaria is under control in much of Indonesia, transmission in Sumba Island remains high, with an incidence as high as 500 cases per 1000 people per year in some areas. This chapter explores the use of insecticide treated nets (ITNs), traditional Sumbanese mosquito control methods, as well as the role of community-based health workers (kaders) and integrated health service posts (posyandu), to combat malaria. Focus group discussions (n = 7) and key informant interviews (n = 14) were conducted with religious leaders, health workers, and women’s group leaders and were stratified by urban/rural location and malaria incidence. Results indicate that environmental conditions, such as high temperatures, were deterrents to regular use. Furthermore, our results suggest that community-embedded health workers, kaders, and health service posts, posyandu, play an important role in information dissemination related to mosquitoes and mosquito-borne diseases as well as the distribution and use of ITNs. Chapter 3 aims to investigate local knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to mosquito control and malaria prevention in East Sumba Island, Indonesia through a cross-sectional household survey (n = 757) informed by previously collected qualitative data found in Chapter 2. The cross-sectional household surveys were conducted across six study sites in East Sumba Regency, Indonesia in urban and rural areas with both high and low malaria incidence. Logistic/multinomial regressions examined sociodemographic relationships to themes found within the household surveys. Further, this study utilizes and expands the traditional Health Belief Model to understand mosquito control and malaria prevention behaviors, particularly as they are impacted by gender, socioeconomics, and geographic location. This study uncovered survey respondents’ attitudes, perceptions, and acceptance of the novel spatial repellent use (n = 719) with 95% of study participants expressing a likelihood of using spatial repellent. This demonstrated early buy-in to novel techniques to control mosquitoes. Additionally, results from this study include the influence of risk perception on a willingness to take actions to control mosquitoes to prevent malaria such as clearing tall grass and/or brush, eliminating mosquito breeding habitats, willingness to sell or deliver mosquito control products, and a willingness to educate the community about such measures. Chapter 4 investigates the role of films used as a key component for World Geography (GEA 1000), an undergraduate course that completes a university-wide cross-cultural studies requirement. Utilizing films, particularly those sourced from underrepresented regions, introduced students to local and situated knowledges outside their typical perspectives and lived experiences. The course was taught remotely during a six-week Summer session in 2020 during the SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pandemic. The films used cover a wide range of topics such as poverty, war, climate change, migration, and other key subjects. Upon watching the films, students were then instructed to take a short assessment to evaluate their comprehension of the film content. At the completion of the course, students expressed (through course evaluations) that this format helped contextualize geographic themes and world events as well as served as a learning tool in addition to more traditional methods.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Uncovering Word Painting and Motivic Structures Within Paul Hindemith's Das Marienleben

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Das Marienleben, Motive, Paul Hindemith, Word Painting

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study is to highlight word painting and motivic material in Paul Hindemith’s Das Marienleben. Throughout history, these devices have been compositional techniques used by many composers. This treatise will be helpful in interpreting Hindemith’s Das Marienleben and approaching the music from an experimental view. The life of Mary is shrouded in mystery; the Bible says little about her before she is visited by Gabriel or after Jesus ascends to heaven. Rilke uses poetic license to fill out the unknown details of Mary’s life and Hindemith interprets the poetry by creating a dynamic song cycle that starts with Mary’s birth and concludes with her own ascension into heaven. This study includes figures with highlighted motives, discussion of significant moments within the music, and scriptural passages and poetry that introduce each song. Readers will also find a complete IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet) transcription, a glossary of terminology, and a translated edition of Hindemith’s opening remarks on the cycle. The last scholarly writings about Das Marienleben were published over twenty years ago and this treatise aims to bring a new perspective in approaching his music.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Lyre as a Sonic Icon in the Italian Renaissance

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Early Music, Italian Renaissance, Kithara, Lyre, Marsilio Ficino, Occultism

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis explores the musical, metaphorical, and metaphysical symbolism of the lyre as a term, as an image, and as a physical instrument in fourteenth through sixteenth centuries Italy, analyzing evidence to argue that it acted as a sonic icon. The term sonic icon refers to the visual and sonic importance of this instrument held by scholars, musicians, and artists during this period. This can be seen through multivalences surrounding the lyre as a term, image, or stringed instrument of many types, as a mythical and philosophical symbol, and as a tool for musical performances, including those which involved healing and connections to esoteric practices. The lyre’s importance was re-emphasized through an “early music” revival during this time period where humanist scholars attempted the application and synthesis of their understanding of music in Greek and Roman antiquity with contemporary performances. The present study includes a brief introduction to the lyre and musical practices of antiquity followed by considerations of performance practice, esoteric beliefs, as well as visual and sonic symbolic representations of the instrument. In doing so, I will argue that humanists were engaging in a mimetic relationship with this instrument as an abstract concept in their attempts to re-sound this music, providing an additional lens through which one can view the presence of antiquity in the Italian Renaissance.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE EFFECT OF FLASHCARDS ON THE FACTUAL KNOWLEDGE AND CONCEPTUAL UNDERSTANDING OF STUDENT ATHLETES.

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: athletic coaching, flashcard, spaced repetition, Testing effect

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Flashcards are with us from our very earliest learning experiences. As infants, we learn to speak words from flashcard pictures. As toddlers, we are introduced to vocabulary concepts and thinking skills with flashcards. In early learning experiences we learn facts, languages, associations, even social skills. Flashcards remain highly prevalent in higher education, especially medical education, vocabulary, language learning, as well as mathematics and psychology. Learners at the highest levels augment their knowledge with flashcards. What actually makes these learning tools so ubiquitous and, ultimately, effective?Two major components of how flashcards work are the testing effect and spaced repetition. The purpose of this quasi-experimental study is to understand the relationship between these elements and flashcard use, particularly in an athletic setting. Athletic coaches spend a considerable amount of time teaching basic factual information (lower level) to their athletes. As a result, less time is spent on higher-level learning such as applying and analyzing. A secondary purpose of this study is to determine if flashcards can effectively be used to help athletes demonstrate higher-level application principles. To accomplish this, this study will introduce an asynchronous, digital flashcard app as an intervention tool for high school American football coaching. The app will track usage data and results, which will be used to determine if there is any effect on student exam scores. Ultimately, it is hoped that the results offer new tools and approaches to athletic coaching pedagogy.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring Therapeutic Techniques and Their Importance Among Music Therapists Working with Survivors of Trauma: A Mixed-Methods Study

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Music Therapy, Survivors of Trauma, Trauma, Trauma Symptomatology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Trauma events have been documented throughout the continuum of life, and there continues to be a need among helping professionals to work with those who experience trauma. The field of music therapy has experienced a gap in scholarship and education, surrounding trauma work in areas such as mental health, medical health, physical health, and social health. Trauma symptomatology is unpredictable in how it manifests within each individual, making it difficult to treat. Additionally, trauma responses contain much cross-diagnosis symptomatology. Some music therapists strive to provide services to those with trauma symptoms; however, trauma-focused education and training is still growing within the field. This research sought to identify trauma-focused information and clinical insights to assist music therapists who work with survivors of trauma.

To address the gap in the music therapy literature, a mixed-methods approach was used, along with an extensive review of the current literature related to trauma was completed. Resources during this review were included both within the music therapy umbrella, as well as those that fell within other helping professions, such as social work, psychology, education, and medicine. The literature identified a myriad of situations and events in which trauma responses have occurred. Many of these scenarios coincide in areas of work in which music therapy thrives.

Subsequently, music therapists who have worked with survivors of trauma or trauma symptomatology were interviewed on their perceptions of music therapy work within the field of trauma (N = 10). Participant interview responses were then incorporated into common thematic material that emerged among the literature and between participants. Results showed a lack of knowledge and prior trainings in the trauma-focused area that was remedied by individuals seeking additional degrees outside the field and/or additional training through continuing education. Respondents reported both personal and non-personal connections to the area of therapy. Respondents’ therapeutic approaches, goals, and music therapy interventions were also documented. Finally, personal perceptions and changes of therapists resulting from providing services in this area were discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Artists in Residence: Music Therapy Students in Intergenerational Relationships with Older Adults residing in an Assisted Living Facility

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Assisted Living Facilities, Intergenerational Relationships, Music, Music Therapy, Music Therapy Students, Older Adults

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this thesis was to examine the intergenerational relationships that can be formed between music therapy students (n=2) and older adults residing in an assisted living facility (n=12). Additionally, this study aimed to identify if there are any changes in the perceptions of older adults and music therapy students’ perceptions of one another and to assess if there were any benefits of intergenerational relationships on the mental health and well-being of older adults residing in an assisted living facility. Specifically, this study explored if there was a difference in the 1) quality of life and well-being of older adults, 2) perceptions of opposing generations (college students and older adults who live in an Assisted Living Facility), 3) self-reported depression levels of older adults, and 4) self-reported anxiety levels of older adults after engaging in intergenerational relationships through music. This study used a mixed-methods design through 4 different survey measures and anecdotal interviews. Results indicated that there were improvements in all measures, although not statistically significant. Further results and implications are discussed within the paper.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Heatwaves in Florida and Their Future

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Florida, in the southeast US, is vulnerable to heatwaves due to its unique geolocation, exacerbated by both high temperature and humidity. To better understand the future impact on heatwave events over Florida we first conduct a retrospective analysis of these heat wave events in the current century using atmospheric reanalysis dataset (ERA5) as a verification dataset to verify two decades of simulations from a relatively high-resolution coupled ocean-atmosphere (RSM-ROMS) and atmosphere (RSM) only regional models. The analysis investigates the length, intensity, and characteristic kinematic and thermodynamic features of heatwave events over Florida between 1986-2005. After ascertaining the fidelity of the models from this retrospective analysis we proceeded to examine the future projection of the heatwave events for the decades of 2041-2060. The future projections are presented only for RSM since the differences from RSM-ROMS for the isolated heatwave events was found to be insignificant for the current and the future periods. We found the projected change of earlier first and later last dates of future heatwave events are associated with a projected increase in the mean surface temperature, a reduction of surface humidity, and a westward dislocation of the North Atlantic Subtropical High. Similarly, we also find that the frequency of the one, two, three, four, and five day heatwave events increase in the mid-21st century relative to the late-20th century period.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PRESERVICE TEACHERS' PERCEPTIONS AND READINESS ENTERING CULTURALLY AND LINGUISTICALLY DIVERSE CLASSROOMS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study addresses preservice teachers’ self-efficacy in understanding culturally responsive pedagogy (CRP) and their readiness to teach in CLD classrooms. This study analyzed preservice teachers' beliefs in CRP and the challenges or barriers that implementation may present. Also, the research examined preservice teachers' self-efficacy about entering the teaching field. The nation's growing diversity requires that educators address their biases and have confidence in delivering instruction to meet the needs of today's culturally and linguistically diverse student population. The achievement gap between Black and Brown students of color and White students has been well documented, and it is essential to close the gap that is only growing post-pandemic. With the intense racial climate of late, the implications for addressing culturally responsive pedagogy have never been more important as its essence is being attacked and “banned” across the nation. This study looks to further the conversation on the readiness of educators to teach in our nation’s and specifically the state of Florida’s CLD schools with instructional equity at the core and determine what more teacher education programs may need to do to address this need.

DISS_description.DISS_title: David Hewitt: The South African Guitarist and His Compositions

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Classical Guitar, David Hewitt, Maskanda, South Africa

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: South African guitarist and composer David Hewitt (1947-2001) left the classical guitar repertoire a collection of works that reflect his experiences and inspirations from western traditions of guitar along with his fascinations with Zulu maskanda music. The resulting compositions constitute a body of work that is utterly unique and dramatically underrepresented in the classical guitar repertoire today. The purpose of this treatise is to offer a hearty introduction to the classical guitarist David Hewitt and his innovative overlap of seemingly polarized worlds of guitar practice. Exploring Hewitt’s training through western and classical idioms with his collaborative and creative maturation into native South African musics will offer an appropriate foundation from which to familiarize guitarists seeking to diversify their repertoire. Ambitious results of this document will awaken a resonance with David Hewitt’s story among guitarists globally, recognizing not the polarity of his perspective but the overwhelming similarities of his experiences and influences to a modern classical guitarist’s viewpoint. Uncovering Hewitt’s works resting in relative obscurity will enrich concert programs for an instrument whose lean repertoire will benefit from an addition of melodic and imaginative African-born compositions from a composer unavailable to exhibit them himself.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NUCLEAR STRUCTURE OF HIGH SPIN STATES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: alpha, deuteron, Direct Reaction, gamma, High Spin, Shell Model

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Microscopic nuclear shell model calculations have been advancing in capability over the last 40years. Florida State University’s experimental nuclear structure group has participated in this advancement with the introduction of the FSU interaction in 2019. To provide new data and test out the theoretical predictions of the FSU interaction the excited, high spin structure of two nuclei are studied. The first, 37Ar, was studied using high resolution gamma spectroscopy following fusion evaporation compound reaction. This data was from an experiment at Argonne National Lab in 2017 with GRETINA (Gamma-Ray Energy Tracking In-beam Nuclear Array). Results presented herein show excellent agreement with nuclear states calculated with the FSU interaction. Several gamma transitions and levels not published before the start of the analysis are pointed out along with the next member of the yrast band. The second nucleus, 29Si, was studied using a direct reaction, 27Al(α, d)29Si. Of particular interest for this dissertation the (α, d) reaction was first studied by a group at Berkeley lab, who showed it selectively populates particular states [1]. Importantly the most strongly populated state by (α, d) is also the yrast fully aligned state of particular interest for comparison to the FSU interaction. Deuteron spectra of 27Al(α, d)29Si is presented up to the deuteron separation energy. Results of spectroscopic factor calculations are presented for deuteron cluster formation. A candidate peak for the fully aligned state is found at 13.7 MeV. Results from the study of both nuclei are presented in comparison to the FSU interaction. Agreement is found between FSU interaction and both nuclei for states along and near the yrast band. The fully aligned state in 29Si shows slight disagreement with the FSU interaction in absolute value, but on a relative basis the agreement is consistent with previous results from other nuclei lower in excitation energy, like 37Ar

DISS_description.DISS_title: Access, Inclusion, and Age: Supporting Adult Learners in a Federal STEM Internship

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Adult Education, Age, Internship, NASA, STEM Education, Workforce Development

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Internships are considered "high-impact practices" offering students transformative opportunities to develop new skills and professional identities while immersed in workplace culture. They have also been pinpointed as key to improving student success and employment within science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. However, much of what is known about internships has centered around the experiences of adolescents pursuing traditional academic paths, despite the presence of many nontraditional adult degree-seekers in higher education. As the STEM pipeline gives way to a "pathways" approach and an evolving high-tech economy demands increasing flexibility and worker mobility, stakeholders must consider the impact of age on the internship experience from entry to exit. This exploratory dissertation in practice does this by identifying common challenges encountered by adults pursuing internships and examining ways in which their life course trajectories and structural internship features interplay to create them. Data gathered through semi-structured interviews of 13 adult undergraduates pursuing STEM careers and interning with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is approached through a life course theoretical lens in conjunction with the Internship Process Model developed by Hora et al. (2020a). Thematic analysis reveals common patterns in the experiences of adults throughout the internship process which fall into the overarching categories of challenging logistics, social marginalization, and a deficient recognition of work history. Based on these findings, recommendations are offered to develop a NASA Internship Program which is more accessible and inclusive for an increasingly age-diverse student population.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AMULETS AND ADORNMENTS: THE VALUE OF FINGER RINGS AT MISSION SITES IN LA FLORIDA

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Finger rings are some of the earliest European artifacts brought to the Americas. Columbus is recorded giving them to the Taíno Indians during his early explorations in the 1490s (Las Casas 1965:288). In addition to this, they are the second-most frequently appearing jewelry item at Spanish colonial sites, to beads (Deagan 2002:122). However, almost no research has been published on finger rings from Spanish Florida. There is a plethora of studies about French Jesuit rings, but finger rings at seventeenth century Spanish Mission sites existed in a much different context. This thesis aims to investigate the significance and meaning of finger rings in mission life at three sites from La Florida: Santa Catalina de Guale (9LI274), San Pedro y San Pablo de Patale (8LE152), and San Luis de Talimali (8LE4). Each site’s assemblage of finger rings differed drastically and reflected the individual societies of the missions. To answer my question, I use a methodology by Harris (2017) that investigates the desirability of an object from different perspectives. The methodology includes five principles by which objects are valued: material properties, expense and exclusivity, sensory appeal, object biography, and fungibility. This methodology combined with an understanding of the context of the finger rings allows me to evaluate the significance of the finger rings at each mission site. The results of this analysis are that finger rings were significant because they could be used as amulets, objects with supernatural properties, or as adornment that displayed an individual’s status. This thesis provides a foundation for future research on finger rings at Spanish colonial sites and offers insight on cultural identity and continuity at Spanish Missions in La Florida.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Music and Emotion Identification: Categorization of YouTube Videos and Possible Uses for Music Therapy

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Emotion, Identification, Music

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Working in behavioral health, one sees many different people, function levels, and mental illness. Many patients appear to struggle with identifying emotion. In many groups, emotion has been discussed and there has been many times where different group members have had vastly different answers when asked about emotion in relation to a song or lyrics. The purpose of this study was conducted to investigate the potential usefulness of YouTube videos as a music therapy aid to teach emotion identification through music. A YouTube search was conducted on February 2, 2023, using the search term “music emotion identification.” The first 50 videos at or under an 11-minute runtime were preliminarily screened, and two duplicates were removed. This resulted in 48 videos that were processed to determine if they met inclusion criteria. Of the 48 possible videos for inclusion, 12 met the criteria to be included. Data were extracted from these videos; these data included audience, video format, and a brief summary. Of the 12 videos that met inclusion criteria, most were targeted towards children, contained emotion identification content, and had education as a main theme. Half of the videos meeting inclusion criteria paired music with visual aspects of the video and half used music as background for the video content. Videos that mentioned music therapy were flagged and were revisited to determine whether or not music therapy was present such as a live demonstration or in-depth discussion. Future research could include creating an experiment using these videos to determine if they are effective in improving emotion identification skills. Other considerations include determining if emotion identification skill affects a person’s ability to recognize and control their emotions.
Keywords: Music emotion identification, music therapy, YouTube, clinical relevance.

DISS_description.DISS_title: FINDING BLISS: THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A CULTURALLY-BASED MINDFULNESS INTERVENTION WITHIN AN URBAN TITLE I ELEMENTARY SCHOOL CONTEXT

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: African American youth, Elementary education, Mindfulness, Mindfulness-based intervention, Research based interventions, Social emotional learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Mindfulness research is growing as educators and practitioners place emphasis on social emotional learning (SEL). Evidence supports mindfulness benefits are both physical and mental to include lowering blood pressure, decreased anxiety, increased executive functioning, and increased ability to pay attention. While the benefits of mindfulness practice are being explored and researched more than ever before, most studies use adults and don’t focus on minority populations. Of studies that have focussed on youth, few use elementary children and even fewer have focused on minority youth for their target population. This study explores the effectiveness and implementation of a mindfulness intervention created intentionally for elementary students attending an urban title I school. In an aim to empower students and make the content for culturally relevant and responsive, I used Patricia Young’s (2009b) ID-TABLET and John Keller’s (1987a) ARCS model as theoretical frameworks to develop and implement an e-book entitled Finding BLISS that taught key concepts of mindfulness and allowed for mindfulness practice. Finding BLISS incorporated characters, voices, and scenarios familiar with the target audience, urban youth, while introducing them to mindfulness as a helpful practice to cope with stress. I used both qualitative and quantitative analysis to determine participant satisfaction and the overall impact of Finding BLISS via the Child Adolescent Mindfulness Measure (CAMM), Instructional Materials Motivational Survey (IMMS), knowledge of mindfulness questionnaire, and focus groups. Data analysis showed a significant difference between pre to post measures on knowledge of mindfulness but no change in actual levels of participant mindfulness. Data also indicated participants were satisfied with the intervention, thought it was relevant, and made recommendations to better capture and sustain their attention.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Risk aversion in Kyle-Back models

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Information asymmetry, Kyle-Back model, Optimal transport, Quasilinear PDE, Risk-averse informed trader

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: One of the canonical models in market microstructure has been the Kyle-Back models. The popularity and importance of these models have stemmed from the fact that it helps us obtain liquidity characteristics of the market in equilibrium. It also gives an insight into the price impact which arises from the interaction among the various market participants.

In this dissertation, we mainly study the continuous time Kyle-Back models in the presence of a risk-averse informed trader. In the first part, we consider the case where there is only one stock in the market. In addition to this, the risk-averse insider has an exponential type utility, and the belief of the market maker on the distribution of the price at the final time is allowed to be non-Gaussian. We show that the problem of the existence of equilibrium in Kyle's continuous time insider trading model can be solved by considering a forward-backward system coupled via an optimal transport type constraint at maturity. The forward component is a stochastic differential equation representing an endogenously determined state variable and the backward component is a quasilinear parabolic equation representing the pricing function. We also study the properties of the equilibrium obtained for a small enough risk aversion parameter.

In the second part, we extend the theory into the multi-dimension setup. Like in the first part, we still have one risk-averse informed trader, but now we allow the market participants to trade in multiple stocks. We show the existence of equilibrium even when the belief of the market maker is non-Gaussian. The equilibrium is constructed by considering a Fokker-Planck equation and a system of partial differential equations that are coupled with an optimal transport type constraint at maturity. We also study the properties of the equilibrium that we established.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Symphonic Poems for Wind Ensemble

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: band, composition, contemporary, post-minimalist, wind ensemble

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Symphonic Poems is a collection of two movements Arcadian Flair (06:30) and The Wing of a Lark (8:30) written for wind ensemble. For inspiration, I looked to notable composers John Corigliano, John Mackey, Adam Schoenberg, and Joseph Schwantner. Inspired by the sounds of video games, Arcadian Flair is meant to represent the childhood wonder of a video arcade. Post-minimalist in style, the work incorporates fun, exciting textures, and grooving bass lines reminiscent of many video game soundtracks. Arcadian Flair is comprised of 3 main sections: 2 sections drawing on similar motives followed by a coda. The harmonic structure was systematically constructed through chaining together diatonic pentachords. These pentachords were ordered to create the sharp chromatic modulations between tonal centers of the first two sections. The coda features a chromatic sequence alternating suspended chords with inverted major triads while a slow melody provides contrast to the rapid texture that brings the movement to a climatic close. The Wing of a Lark is inspired by a simple 6 note motive [C-B-C-G-G-E] borrowed from a good friend of mine Jaron Brown. This motive is interwoven into most musical aspects of the movement. The motive itself serves as a melody and is fragmented into various ostinato. The intervallic content informed much of the harmonic nature by incorporating the half-step as sudden harmonic shifts and fifths as quintal harmony. The movement is comprised of many short contrasting sections that form a loose narrative of a bird in flight. Larks are birds that sound like they are singing while in flight, thus much of the melodic content is short & fragmented, has a wide range, or comprises of fast rhythms as a bird call might. Over the course of the movement one can hear a rise and fall, often occurring at different rates, meant to depict how a bird may fly in the various air streams in the sky.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Experiences of Perfectionistic Collegiate Classical Musicians

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: classical, mental, perfectionism, performance, saxophone, sport psychology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Classical musicians perform in a domain where success and failure hinges on the opinions of others. Thus, the value of perfection in pursuit of high performance is commonly ingrained in musicians early in their training. Much of the quantitative research on perfectionism focuses on outcomes, but qualitative investigations can help to advance understanding of the experiences of different types of perfectionists in competitive settings (Gotwals & Spencer-Cavaliere, 2014; Hill et al., 2015; Howle & Eklund, 2017; Mallison-Howard et al., 2018; Sellars et al., 2016; Stoeber, 2011). Therefore, the primary purpose of this study was to further understand the experiences of perfectionism by exploring collegiate classical musicians’ perceptions, sources, and consequences of perfectionism. The secondary purpose was to develop a model that can be applied to understand both Mixed Perfectionists’ and Pure-Personal Standards Perfectionists’ experiences. Self-identified Mixed Perfectionists and Pure-Personal Standards Perfectionists (n=12) from a collegiate saxophone studio were interviewed for this study. Participants also completed a demographics assessment and the Sport-Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale-2 (Gotwols & Dunn, 2009). A grounded theory approach was used to guide data analysis and propose the “Dynamics of the Experiences of Perfectionism Model” (Strauss & Corbin, 1998). The category labeled perceptions was identified as the core phenomenon of the model, meaning that the entire experience of perfectionism hinges on the performer’s perceptions. Several factors were found to play a role in participants’ experiences of perfectionism. These factors included early experiences, personal standards, concerns over mistakes, perceptions of self, perceptions of the environment, perceptions of the director and peers, definitions of effective performance, preparation, appraisals, perceptions of the audience, attributions, and emotional and behavioral consequences. The proposed model explains how these factors build off each other and layer in a way that illustrates the development of perfectionism and perfectionistic tendencies over time. Results are discussed in relationship to the previous literature along with highlighting applications for music program directors and faculty, musicians, and potential intervention points for mental performance consultants.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PROGRAM AND NARRATIVE IN ANDRÁS HAMARY’S PIANO MUSIC: ANALYSES OF JELEK (1998) AND DER KLEINE PRINZ (2016)

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The main purpose of this treatise is to draw attention to András Hamary’s piano music. This is done through careful analysis of his two major piano works containing extra-musical inspirations, Jelek and Der Kleine Prinz. Formal, harmonic, motivic, and gestural analyses are employed as they relate to the narrative in the music. The extra-musical inspirations and references are also examined in terms of how much they drive the music’s texture and form. Lastly, the pedagogical merits of the works and their significance in the canon of piano literature are discussed. An in-depth look at both works’ technical and musical challenges are addressed with some recommended approaches and solutions that aim to help pianists who would like to tackle Hamary’s music. Looking into both works not only reveals the creativity in Hamary’s compositional language but also sheds new light on possible perceptions of different structures and narrative that exist in music. This treatise paves the way for future performers and researchers to know and to understand Hamary’s dynamic compositions. I genuinely hope that the music of Hamary will become better known to performers, teachers, and scholars.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THROUGH THE BARS AND BEHIND A DESK: THE EFFECTS OF HOUSEHOLD MEMBER INCARCERATION ON STUDENTS DURING THE SCHOOL DAY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study takes a look at the many effects having an incarcerated household member has on students during the school day. In order to gain a better understanding of these effects, twelve middle school teachers were interviewed about their experiences with these students. According to the teachers interviewed the study found the following.Students often have lower academic performance, more behavior problems, and parents who are simply overwhelmed by their situation. Teachers stated they have not had enough training provided to help them support their students in this situation. Additionally, they felt the school counselors are overwhelmed and there are not enough mental health supports for students in the building. Based on these findings I concluded that teachers would like to see more training to teach them how to deal with student trauma, more mental health professionals in the school building, more extracurricular activities that provide the opportunity for mentorship, and a list of community resources that they can share with families who might need extra help.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UNDERSTANDING BEGINNING ELEMENTARY SCHOOL TEACHERS’ PERCEPTIONS AND EXPERIENCES OF THE HAWAI’I TEACHER INDUCTION PROGRAM IN THE LAULIMA COMPLEX

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The rate at which teacher turnover is taking place in Hawai'i is a concern for many administrators and staff members in K-12 schools because of the negative impact it is having throughout the schools. Hawai'i ranks first in the country for teacher turnover rate. According to the Learning Policy Institute, 4.9% of teachers in Hawai’i are uncertified, which is nearly double the national average (2.6%). In the 2018-2019 school year, Hawai’i experienced 1,029 vacant teaching positions out of approx. 13,000. It is estimated that more than 60,000 students are taught by an under-qualified teacher every year in Hawai’i (Walker, 2020). The Hawai’i Teacher Induction Program has been implemented with the intent to increase student achievement along with retaining beginning teachers by offering them instructional support. All beginning teachers, in the Hawai’i State Department of Education, are required to participate in a three-year induction program. Beginning teachers are provided with intensive mentorship for the first two years, and a third year of less intensive mentorship, along with an option to participate in professional learning communities and attend outings to help get acclimated and familiar with the Hawaiian culture. However, very little is known about how beginning teachers perceive the induction program or what components beginning teachers find most and least beneficial. Through this qualitative, exploratory, case study, semi-structured, in-depth interviews were conducted to explore how beginning elementary school teachers experience and perceive the Hawaii Teacher Induction Program in the Laulima Complex. Purposive sampling was used to identify potential participants. Nine teachers, across four elementary schools throughout the Laulima Complex on Maui, were interviewed. Thematic analysis yielded the following findings: beginning teachers from the mainland experience feelings of isolation, teaching is more stressful than expected, the Educator Effectiveness System is challenging and overwhelming, mentoring was the only component experienced by all beginning teachers, availability of mentors differed from school to school, mentors provided professional and emotional support, the decision to stay in teaching was based more on individual factors rather than experiences with the Hawai’i Teacher Induction Program, and many beginning teachers felt mentoring was one factor to consider when making a decision to stay in education.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TEACHERS’ UNDERSTANDINGS OF L2 ACQUISITION, STRATEGIES TO TEACH ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS, AND THE CHALLENGES THEY FACE WHEN TEACHING THESE STUDENTS: AN EXPLORATORY CASE STUDY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Achievement gap, ELL, English Language Learner, ESOL Strategies, Second language acquisition, Teachers' Perceptions

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Despite the promise of equal education opportunities for all students in the nation, the achievement/opportunity gap between English language learners (ELLs) and their non-ELLs peers persists. Time, effort, and resources of all kids have been invested in educational reforms to improve these students’ outcomes without success (Darling-Hammond, 2007; Lopez & Iribarren, 2014; Polat et al., 2016; Soland & Sandilos, 2020). This outcome is also mirrored at a public middle school in Valley County (pseudonym) in Florida. Through semi-structured in-depth interviews and classroom observations, this single-case, qualitative study sought to explore teachers’ understandings of the second language acquisition process, what they perceive as best practices, and what they perceive as the most pressing challenges when working with ELLs. Through a thematic approach, nine themes emerged which revealed that participants have a limited repertoire of ESOL strategies and a limited knowledge base of second language learning. Several misconceptions were evident regarding the way ELLs advance their second language and what educators consider barriers to ELLs' academic attainment. This may be the result of the non-participatory role teachers in this study have in ESOL Professional Developments (PDs). Their view of these trainings as ineffective and unpractical may have decreased their motivation to participate. Therefore, the school and district should provide teachers with coaching and meaningful PDs opportunities to help them develop the set of skills needed to better serve this student population.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Nonlinear wave propagation in non-Hermitian media: theory and computation

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Constant intensity waves, Dispersive hydrodynamics, dispersive shock waves, non-Hermitian Riemann problem, nonlinear waves, PT-symmetry

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this thesis, we develop and study two distinct problems in the field of nonlinear waves. The first part of the thesis is connected to the development of a computational algorithm that preserves underlying structure of the simulated initial boundary value problem in the form of multiple global conservation laws or dissipation rate equations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Is conceptual knowledge of suicide necessary for perceiving suicidality?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: conceptual knowledge, semantic satiation, suicide

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Conceptual knowledge about suicide represents a potential necessary cause for experiencing suicidal thoughts and behaviors. Although some indirect evidence for this view exists, this hypothesis has not yet been directly tested. The objective of the current effort was to take steps toward this end. Using a within-subject design, we tested the effects of a semantic satiation protocol targeting the word “suicide” on the subsequent perceptual judgment of suicide-relevant pictures. We also examined the specificity of this satiation effect by exploring the effects on related concepts of “accident” and “murder.” The sample included 104 undergraduate students. On each trial, participants were asked to repeat aloud one of the three words (i.e., “accident,” “murder,” or “suicide”) either three times (prime condition) or 30 times (satiation condition) and decide whether a subsequent picture matched with the word or not. We performed two-way repeated-measures analyses of variance to compare the differences in response latency and accuracy across conditions and trial types. Results indicated that satiation of the word “suicide” slowed accurate categorization of pictures depicting suicide, murder, or accident, and satiation of the words “murder” and “accident” delayed participants’ response latencies on suicide-relevant pictures. Taken together, findings support the hypothesis that semantic satiation can render the suicide concept temporarily less accessible, thereby providing preliminary evidence for the potential causal necessity of conceptual knowledge in perceiving suicidality. Limitations, implications, and future directions of this work are also discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Methodology for the Characterization of Surface Treated High Purity Niobium

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: High-purity niobium is the material of choice for making superconducting radio-frequency cavities for the modern particle accelerator. While making the cavities from the Nb sheet, it goes through a series of processes including chemical and thermal treatments. These treatments affect the microstructural as well as magnetic properties of niobium. In order to optimize the efficiency of Nb cavities, various treatments have been explored. During the last decade, surface modification through impurity diffusion has been extensively explored and found that the quality factor of Nb cavities can be enhanced by impurity diffusion to the niobium surface. The surface treatments that are found to enhance the quality factor include high-temperature nitrogen doping, low-temperature nitrogen infusion, and most recently mid-temperature furnace baking. Even though these treatments have been shown to improve cavity performance, the fundamental understanding of the phenomenon is very limited, and each treatment has its own drawbacks. During the operation of Nb cavities, the oscillating electromagnetic field penetrates the Nb surface only to the 40-200 nm depth. Hence, the cavity performance is dependent largely on the condition of this layer. Thus, a detailed understanding of the effect of different treatments on the Nb surface is essential.Cutting a Nb cavity for the characterization of its surface after different treatments is economically not viable and the characterizing tools are also limited for the cut-out samples. Based on the characterization techniques, the requirements for sample shape and size vary, for example, microscopy, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, ellipsometry etc. require flat samples whereas magnetization measurements are best made using cylindrical samples. Hence, using a coupon sample characterization turns out to be a cost-effective way of probing the effect of different processing steps. In this thesis, I have used surface-characterizing tools such as scanning electron microscopy (SEM), x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and magnetization to explore the effect of some of the recent cavity treatments on the microstructure, chemistry, and magnetic properties of high purity Nb surface. The goal is to construct a coupon-based methodology to explore the effect of different processing treatments.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Choral Director as Stage Director: Creating and Implementing a Staging Concept for Bach’s St. John Passion

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bach, Choral, Choral staging, Choral theatre, St. John Passion, Stage directing

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Choral concerts incorporating theatrical elements have become a trend in the United States and internationally. However, there is little academic literature written about staged choral performances and how choral directors can visualize and physicalize choral works. The purpose of this study is to provide choral conductors a sequential process for creating a staging concept and implementing it in rehearsals with the help of a blocking script. The following research questions have guided the study: (1) What are the components of the conductor’s preparation before creating a staging concept of a choral masterpiece? (2) How do these components contribute to creating a staging concept? (3) How does one transform a concept into a document that increases rehearsal effectiveness? (4) What is the sequence of events in a rehearsal process?

In April 2022, I was fortunate to be involved in a Bach St. John Passion project in Germany as a stage director. Although it was a fully-staged production, this adventure taught me that there is a potential to transform this work into a semi-staged production, which leads to a smaller budget and opens up opportunities for community choirs and college choirs to experience the beauty of choral theatre. This approach is universal to any choral works, from short octavo music to full-scale masterpieces.

The study first identifies various components in a choral piece, such as the libretto, the performing forces, and the musical architecture, that can contribute to creating a staging concept, which can be the stage director’s interpretation of space and time that the story takes place, the (re)characterization of the roles, or the distinctive emphasis of the plot. The objective of such concept is to bring relatability to the modern audience through reflection of the story. This study then adopts the prompt-book methodology and transforms the staging concept into a blocking script, which serves as a solid guideline when working with the performers and increases effectiveness in staging rehearsals. To conclude, this study suggests the sequence of events in the rehearsal process, so conductors will understand how to approach staging a choral piece from a practical perspective. Recommendations for further study are also listed for conductors who aspire to produce staged choral performances regularly.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Extraction and Analysis of 2D and 3D Data from Images and of Phylogenetic Tree Data from RNA and DNA Sequences and Consistency of Spherical Depth on Object Spaces

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: 2D and 3D images form the bulk of object data. 3D configurations are extracted from digital camera images, and the surface of the scene pictured is physically reconstructed up to a similarity, via 3D printing. The virtual reconstructions are examined and analyzed using projective shapes. In particular two sample tests for equality of 3D projective shapes of spacial configurations is tested using the concept of projective quaternion. The oriented projective shape of a configuration is represented as a point on a product of spheres, via the new concept of oriented projective coordinates relative to an oriented projective frame. A two sample test statistic for comparing extrinsic means of matched pairs of oriented projective shapes is introduced here.
