Phosphorylation of signaling transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3)Tyr705, which can be activated by IL-6, was enhanced within all tumor-bearing groups, and was exacerbated by alcohol, whereas suppressor of cytokine signaling 3 (SOCS3), nuclear factor kappa B (NFkB)Ser536, forkhead box protein 1 (FOXO1a)Ser256, and suppressor of Mothers against Decapentaplegic (Smad2)Ser465/467/Smad3Ser423/425, were unaffected by either dietary treatment. However, corresponding to the cancer-driven increase in STAT3Tyr705 was an increase in circulating IL-6 expression in all tumor-bearing groups, except for Chemo. Interestingly, Smad3Ser423/425 was increased only by EtOH, while chemotherapy effectively prevented these changes. A main effect of chemotherapy was present for both circulating IFN-γ and TNF-α, where these cytokines were elevated by chemotherapy regardless of alcohol consumption. Altogether, the ability of chemotherapy to prevent or delay alterations in inflammatory-related proteins does not appear to be affected by chronic alcohol. Skeletal muscle force characteristics are reduced by both cancer and alcohol use; therefore, the purpose of Aim 3 was to define whether chemotherapy preserves skeletal muscle force production impaired during alcohol-enhanced cancer cachexia. In a separate cohort of mice, the identical experimental protocol mentioned above was implemented, however, prior to sacrifice, mice performed in situ skeletal muscle contraction of the triceps surae complex of the lower limb. Tetanic force, twitch maximum, rate of contraction and half relaxation were unaffected by chemotherapy within either dietary treatment, however, all cancer mice experienced an increase in half relaxation time of the triceps surae. Chemotherapy effectively prevented the loss of force during muscular fatigue induced by cancer only within non-alcohol treated mice, indicating that alcohol use prevented these beneficial effects. Furthermore, alcohol increased fatigue within non-chemotherapy treated groups. While force recovery at 5- and 10-minutes post-fatigue was not affected by chemotherapy within either group; recovered force was decreased in alcohol-treated mice compared to non-alcohol. Together, alcohol use reduced force produced during fatigue within non-chemotherapy treated mice. While chemotherapy did not affect tetanic force or twitch characteristics of the triceps surae, in either control or alcohol groups compared to both non-alcohol control and all other tumor-bearing groups, it attenuated fatigue through the preservation of force only within non-alcohol consuming mice. This effect was diminished by alcohol use throughout cancer development, because the alcohol negated the effects of chemotherapy.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Not at Face Value: Exploring whether Whites Exhibit Bias in Categorizing Angry and Happy Black versus White Expressions

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: bias, emotion, expression categorization, ingroup advantage, prejudice, stereotypes

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Accurately decoding emotional facial expressions is necessary for effective human interaction. But person-level features, particularly race, affects the speed and accuracy of which people process certain facial information. Specifically, one line of work indicates that group-level associations impact expression categorization, such that people are faster at categorizing angry Black versus White faces and happy White versus Black faces. Alternatively, there is also evidence that ingroup classification impacts expression categorization, such that people are better at recognizing expressions on own- versus other-race faces. The present research explores these ideas by testing whether race and racial categorization impact expression categorization in three studies. Study 1 is a replication and extension of previous work in which I control for facial features to examine whether skin tone impacts expression categorization. In Study 2, I use skin and feature morphed faces to explore whether expression categorization advantages weaken as the face becomes more racially ambiguous. In Study 3, I control for skin tone to examine whether facial features and racial categorization impact expression categorization. The results indicate that both group-level expression advantages (i.e., Black-angry, White-happy) and an ingroup advantage based on actual race impact expression categorization.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN ATOM-ATOM DISTANCE BASED DEEP LEARNING MODEL FOR PROTEIN- LIGAND DOCKING PREDICTION

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Drug discovery has been known as a long, expensive, and risky process of identifying developing and discovering novel treatments with desired pharmaceutical effect to diseases. Despite advances in computer-aided virtual screening, developing one drug can still take anywhere from 10 to 15 years involving intensive collaboration among scientists, physicians and medical experts and cost billions of dollars to release a new drug to market. Protein-ligand docking plays a fundamental role in drug discovery. Traditional algorithms in searching the binding location and binding pose are extremely expensive and time-consuming. Deep learning-based protein-ligand binding models have achieved many remarkable progresses in the past few years. We designed an atom-atom distance based deep learning model with self-attention mechanism integrated. A preliminary study on Cu2+ and SO42- was firstly conducted and followed by a comprehensive ablation study to detail the contribution of each component of the proposed model, and then we extend it to a larger dataset containing various length of ligands. Results demonstrate that our proposed deep learning architecture achieves promising results comparing to the previous research.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AUTISM AND SONGWRITING: A CASE STUDY EXPLORING THE INTERSECTIONALITY AND PERSONHOOD OF AN AUTISTIC SINGER-SONGWRITER

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Autism, Autistic Identity Development, Ethnography, Intersectionality, Musicology, Singer-Songwriter

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis investigates the songwriting practice and lived experience of a 35-year-old, transgender female musical artist and humanities professor named Mary (pseudonym) through the theoretical lenses of intersectionality and neurodiversity. To my knowledge, this is the first ethnomusicological study exclusively focused on the interaction of songwriting and personhood in a study of an autistic singer-songwriter. I additionally explore how the communicative mode established between Mary and me during this project reveals the methodological value of using the artist’s songs as a starting point for ethnographic engagement. In particular, it demonstrates how this process generated improvised questions in real time that sparked the sharing of meaningful insights and stories on Mary’s part. I then use this methodological model as a template to encourage ethnomusicologists to critically reconsider human communication and interaction within the framework of neurodiversity as culturally informed activities, individualized modes of behavior and habit, and determinants that influence the ways we understand the lives of other people, notwithstanding how “other” might be conceptualized in any given framework.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BAYESIAN STOCHASTIC ATTENTION-BASED NEURAL BAG OF FEATURE MODEL WITH APPLICATIONS IN SEQUENCE DATA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Attention Mechanism, Bag of Feature Model, Radial Basis Function, Sequence Analysis, Variational Bayesian Inference

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Sequence data are extensively studied in numerous domains, such as time series forecasting, audio analysis,Natural Language Processing (NLP), Etc. However, the observed sequences show highly non-stationarity and long-term dependence in real-world applications. Also, the noise term makes the task of modeling and analyzing the underlying generating process more difficult. Digging into the characters of sequence data, either the bias or the specific pattern (e.g., cycle, trend, dependency) needs to be extracted and analyzed. Therefore, statisticians put forward the traditional time series models, such as ARIMA- and GARCH-type models. Also, advanced models that capture the dynamics of sequence called dynamic time warping (DTW), stochastic processing methods such as the Gaussian process and hidden Markov model, and some machine learning models like Random Forest (RF), CNN, and RNN are widely generated for long-range sequence data study given the powerful calculation performance. In this dissertation, we propose another type of model that is originally derived from models other than the traditional sequence data analysis. We propose the Bag of Feature (BoF) type model, originally proposed to build histogram representations based on the extracted features from images. Later, it was shown that the BoF model could also efficiently tackle and process large amounts of complex and high-dimensional sequence data such as video and audio records. BoF model contains three major steps: 1) feature extraction step. 2) the dictionary learning step. 3) the aggregation step. To improve the learning efficiency of the BoF model, we put forward a neural network generalization for the BoF called the Neural Bag of Feature (NBoF) model. Like its predecessor, NBoF can generate a fixed-size histogram vector from variable-size inputs. The NBoF model shares the same framework as its predecessor, which contains a quantization layer constructed with radial basis function and a recurrent accumulation layer. The Neural BoF approach can adjust the input weights and the centers of the RBF neurons and optimize the feature extractor. The NBoF model exhibits a good improvement compared to its unsupervised predecessor. However, in the aggregation step, a fixed-size histogram is calculated simply by averaging all the quantized features, which limits the process of aggregation and dictionary learning to fully take advantage of other data-driven approaches when handling the long-term sequence data. Therefore, a weighing mechanism for the NBoF model on the accumulation layer will help. Specifically, we propose a Bayesian attention module that treats the attention weights as latent random variables. This dissertation introduces a global (soft) data-dependent prior distribution for regularization. The prior can construct a simplex constrained attention posterior distribution via normalizing a reparameterizable distribution (e.g., Gamma distribution, Log-Normal distribution), making the training process differentiable and simple to optimize. Based on the variational inference, the Bayesian attention-based model provides an analytic form that can be applied directly to the NBoF model or any other encoder-decoder system. To investigate the model performance of the proposed BAMNBoF model, we implement the BAMNBoF model on the human behavior analysis dataset (Bar Crawl data), the taxonomical sound resources sequence (UrbanSound 8K) dataset, and also the financial time series classification (FI 2010 data and one simulated high-frequency trading data) and then compare it with NBoF-type models, Attention Neural Bag of Feature (ANBoF) model and also other unsupervised classifiers (random forest, MLP) and supervised neural networks (CNN, LSTM, GRU) with cross-validation schemes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TWO ESSAYS ON CROWDFUNDING AND CONSUMER RETURNS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Consumer Returns, COVID-19, Crowfunding, Service Recovery, SME Financing

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: During my childhood, my family owned a small convenience store that served members of our community. However, our family business had to close because of customers who failed to pay. I find that small businesses tend to be more susceptible to unexpected internal and external forces than their larger counterparts. Small businesses constitute the economy’s lifeblood, but they obviously need more help and support than large companies. I am thus interested in researching the funding-related and operational difficulties that small retailers and startups face and especially what I can do to help them survive these challenges.My first dissertation research focuses on how crowdfunding platforms can help protect economically struggling entrepreneurs during the COVID-19 pandemic. Crowdfunding is a new technology platform providing access to two parties: entrepreneurs and SMEs who launch campaigns to collect money and funders who visit the platform and decide whether to support the project. Despite only being around since 2009, crowdfunding has become a popular entrepreneurship financing option and is catching up to traditional financing channels like venture capital. I propose that such a fast-growing online technology platform offers a vital financing resource for financially constrained entrepreneurs during the pandemic. My empirical analysis results confirm my proposition that the number of funders, the size of their contributions, and their total investment amounts all increased with the increased severity of COVID-19, challenging the existing belief that a crisis has a negative effect on entrepreneurship financing. I further examine that one plausible reason for funders’ increasing investment demand is altruism-- funders are more willing to support and help entrepreneurs to bring their projects to life when they are struggling financially due to COVID-19. This result is consistent with current findings about the altruistic nature of funders noted in the literature. However, on the supply side, entrepreneurs have reduced their project-launching activities despite more financing opportunities on the demand side. I therefore urge entrepreneurs to launch new ventures to tap into crowdfunding resources. My second dissertation paper focuses on consumers’ response to a product failure: product returns. Many retailers treat product returns as an evil because returns hurt their bottom line. However, researchers have pointed out recently that a return serves as another customer touchpoint to enhance consumer relationships. A superior return experience can turn angry, frustrated customers into happy ones so that they increase their purchases in the future. While existing research focuses on the overall effect of returns on future consumer purchases, I question whether this effect applies to all returns. I classify consumer returns based on the reason for the return—the wrong size, not liking the item, disappointment with the quality, and other reasons. Then I examine how the reason for the return impacts future consumer purchases. My regression results suggest that only sizing returns increase the likelihood of consumer repurchases. In contrast, items returned because the consumer doesn’t like the product decrease consumer repurchases and returns based on quality concerns do not significantly affect consumer repurchases. I explain my results based on the attribution theory: customers return reasons influence how they blame a seller and then how they respond. For example, sizing returns, at least partially, can be self-ascribed to consumers because consumers’ body dimensions— height, chest size, waist size, and so on—vary significantly, and so designing a product to fit everyone can be challenging. Due to self- attribution, customers tend to have a lower initial dissatisfaction caused by a return event, which a redress process (i.e., a good return experience) can easily recover. Our paper contributes to consumer return literature by addressing the rarity of return-reason-related research. We also provide important managerial insights to improve retailers' return service recovery practices and customer value evaluation using return reason data.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Improving the Precision of Type Ia Supernova Cosmology

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: 03fg-like type Ia Supernova, Cosmology, NIR spectra, Spectral Template, Supernova, Type Ia supernova Cosmology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) mark the beginning and the end of stellar evolution. They are one of the most powerful cosmological probes in our universe thanks to their high intrinsic luminosities and standardizable properties. In the 1990s, the observation of SNe Ia led to the discovery of the accelerating cosmic expansion that was awarded the Nobel Prize in 2011. Despite decades of advancements, the exact details of progenitor systems (i.e. what exploded), explosion mechanisms (i.e., how they exploded), and evolution effect (i.e. are the nearby population the same as those in the early universe?) are still not fully understood yet. With more advanced observation surveys forthcoming in the near future, such as those on board the Vera C. Rubin Observatory and the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope, the systematic uncertainties of SNe Ia observations will continue to dominate the error budget of their distance measurements. This dissertation is motivated to improve the precision of SN~Ia cosmology by understanding the physics and diversity and SNe Ia, as well as improving the astronomical tools needed for cosmological purposes.

Photometric and spectroscopic observational studies of the first homogenous sample of the peculiar 03fg-like SNe Ia obtained by the Carnegie Supernovae Project (CSP) are conducted to investigate the physics of SNe Ia. 03fg-like events are usually more luminous than the normal SNe Ia and exhibit peculiar light-curve shapes in the redder filters, such as the weak or missing secondary maxima and the delayed peak time in iYJH bands. Spectroscopically, 03fg-like SN Ia show peculiar features in both optical and near-infrared (NIR) regions, such as the stronger C, slower Si, and the lack of the H-band break. One of the most extreme objects within this subgroup, ASASSN-15hy, is used for the case study of an envelope model that could potentially explain all 03fg-like SNe~Ia. It is found that a core degenerate scenario, an explosion of a degenerate white dwarf core inside a nondegenerate envelope, with a transition from deflagration to detonation can explain the observed peculiar properties. In the case of ASASSN-15hy, the low metallicity of the progenitor is a key aspect of the model explanation. In fact, a low-metallicity host environment is a shared preference among these 03fg-like SNe~Ia. Such host environment is more common in the early universe, which brings up the concern that 03fg-like SNe~Ia may be a problem for high-redshift SN~Ia cosmology due to detection bias and potential evolution preference. Therefore, more detailed observational and theoretical studies of these events are strongly recommended.

Another main focus of this dissertation is on the development of a new NIR spectral template of SNe Ia that captures the feature variations that are correlated with the light-curve shapes. Compared to optical observations, NIR observations of SN Ia are less sensitive to dust and have more uniform peak luminosities, which are beneficial for cosmological purposes. A spectral template is usually needed to fit the light curves of SNe Ia accurately in order to estimate the distance. However, the NIR part of the existing spectral templates lacks an accurate description of the intrinsic spectral variations. Using the largest and most homogeneous collection of NIR spectra of SNe Ia to date collected by CSP-II, we are able to explore the NIR spectral diversity of SNe Ia and build a new NIR spectra template. Principal component analysis and Gaussian process regression are used for the template construction, which reduces data dimensionality and models the parameter dependence, respectively. Using the new template reduces the systematic uncertainties in K-corrections by ~90% compared to those from the Hsiao template. Furthermore, this template can serve as the baseline spectral energy distribution for various light-curve fitters and can identify peculiar spectral features that might point to compelling physics. The NIR spectra data and template presented in this work will substantially improve future SN Ia cosmological experiments, for both nearby and distant samples.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Interpretive Choices in Carl Maria von Weber's Grand Duo Concertant: A Performer's Guide to Different Analytical Methods

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Carl Maria von Weber, musical analysis, musical interpretation, performance

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise explores the interpretive decisions that can be made through different methods of musical analysis. Specifically, this study focuses on Carl Maria von Weber’s Grand Duo Concertant Op. 48 for clarinet and piano. The primary focus is not to suggest an ideal interpretation, but rather show how different analytical methods can lead to different interpretations of the same music with supporting reasoning.

The methods of analysis used were formal analysis (drawing from the work of Willia m Caplin, James Hepokoski and Warren Darcy, and Douglass Green), performance analysis (from Karen McLaughlin Large), narrative analysis (drawing from the methods described by Robert Hatten and Byron Almén), and concatenationism (from Jerrold Levinson). When contextualized with historic accounts of Weber’s focus for composition, general musical styles of the early nineteenth century, and the development for how analysis informs interpretation and performance, this study offers options for how to approach different components of the Grand Duo along with how those interpretive choices could translate to live performance or change the approach the performers take to realize those moments in performance. Naturally, the level of subjectivity in an individual’s performance considerations has to be navigated in a study of this nature, therefore, the suggestions made accommodate for that in showing the interpretive options that the chosen methods of analysis can reach rather than ignoring the subjective element of musical performance and offering an ideal guide to performance based on analysis.
Keywords: musical analysis, musical interpretation, performance, Carl Maria von Weber

DISS_description.DISS_title: Improving IoT Security Based on Network Traffic Analytics

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Anomaly Detection, IoT, IoT Device Identification, IoT Devices, IoT Security, Network Security

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Internet of Things (IoT) has revolutionized how we interact with technology by enabling numerous devices to communicate and autonomously perform tasks in various settings such as homes, enterprises, and smart cities. However, this rapid expansion has also introduced significant security threats due to inherent vulnerabilities, diverse device types, and the vast number of IoT devices. This dissertation addresses critical challenges in IoT security by focusing on network traffic characteristics, IoT device identification, and compromised IoT device detection in smart networks. We perform an extensive analysis of network traffic behaviors for both IoT and non-IoT devices, devise a novel approach for device classification based on network traffic behaviors, profile IoT device behavior, and implement a method for detecting compromised IoT devices in smart environments. Our machine-learning-based IoT device identification approach, iotID, achieves a balanced accuracy score above 99% in identifying deployed IoT devices. Furthermore, we introduce a novel approach for detecting compromised IoT devices, iotADAS, using Deep Autoencoders and the Sequential Probability Ratio Test (SPRT) method. Our research contributes to the creation of more secure and reliable IoT ecosystems by providing an effective solution for detecting compromised IoT devices in smart network environments.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Crystal Bridges - Suite for Wind Ensemble

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Cerulean, Crystal Bridges, Lunar Rendezvous-Circle of Flowers, Sierra Nevada Morning, Wind Ensemble

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Sources for musical composition can come when you least expect it. Such is the case for "Crystal Bridges". Each of the movements that make up this piece are based on a piece of art that I observed at the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Arkansas. I was captivated by many of the pieces of art, but especially by the three that I selected to constitute this piece. The first movement, “Lunar Rendezvous-Circle of Flowers”, is based on Alma Thomas's work of art by the same name. Her piece was inspired by the idea of what her garden might look like from the moon. She uses abstraction and vivid colors to portray her response to technological advances and her own passion. I took the playful and elegant nature of a garden and juxtaposed that idea against the vastness and broadness of space. This movement starts in Alma Thomas's garden, then "zooms-out" to see her garden from space. The piece then zooms back into her garden, giving the movement a variation of an arch form. The second movement, “Sierra Nevada Morning”, is based on Albert Bierstadt's painting of the same name. In his painting, Bierstadt keenly reinforces the theme of romanticism by focusing on both mild and powerful elements of nature, emotion, imagination, and the untainted beauty of the West. What captured my attention most about the painting was Bierstadt's use of luminism and depth. The painting features a calm pond with deer, while stretching up to the skies with bright clouds and mountains towering in the background. I reflect the idea of luminism by using metallic percussion instruments such as the vibraphone, crotales, and glockenspiel to create a "shimmering" effect. The piece itself unfolds from quiet woodwind oscillations that build into expansive, chordal hits, paralleling the growth from the pond to the towering mountains and clouds that can be found in Bierstadt's painting. Lastly, “Cerulean”, the third movement, is based on Carmen Herrera's abstract painting of the same name. This piece takes the listener through some of the perceptions of the painting as observed by various patrons at the museum. Some of the words that I used as inspiration during my compositional process were "bold", "sharp", "valorous", "persistent", "vivid", "soaring", and "light". These were all words that came up in discussion with patrons at the museum. Abstract art is meant to encourage imagination and multiple perspectives, which I represent in this concluding movement.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NAVIGATING CONVERSATIONS ABOUT RACE THROUGH AN INTRODUCTION TO ANTI-RACIST PEDAGOGY FOR PRACTICING TEACHERS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Antiracism, Practicing Teachers, Professional Development, Race

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: It is well documented that with a growing demographic mismatch between a largely white teaching force and an increasingly diverse student body, teacher-student relationships are often impacted by a lack of educator understanding around the effects of racism on students’ lives and educational systems. The utilization of anti-racist pedagogy, which emphasizes the examination of historical and political contexts and the cultivation of critical analysis of individual and systemic structures, presents a suitable approach of introducing and delving into the issue of racial equity in education. This study explores the ways in which practicing teachers in a Title I school navigate conversations about race and react to strategies and activities in an introductory professional learning in-service using the Courageous Conversations framework developed by Glen Singleton. This paper indicates a need for continued, ongoing professional development to move teachers toward an anti-racist mindset and create the context necessary for educators to understand systemic racism and its effects within the educational system.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Heavy Hearts and Minds: A Qualitative Study on the Experience of Nurses During the COVID-19 Pandemic

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In December 2019, a strain of pneumonia named SARS-CoV-2, or Coronavirus Disease 2019 (more commonly known as COVID-19), expeditiously spread worldwide, causing a global pandemic. Though the COVID-19 response in the United States has primarily concentrated on controlling the virus's transmission and reducing deaths, this pandemic has caused a secondary crisis of psychological suffering. The psychological health of frontline healthcare workers and other health workers is often ignored or goes unnoticed (Maunder, 2004; Kang et al., 2020; Robertson et al., 2004; Xiang et al., 2020); however, the mental and emotional vulnerability of healthcare workers was identified as a critical issue during the pandemic (Holmes et al., 2020). A qualitative study was performed using grounded analysis to (1) determine the types of trauma experienced by nurses responding to the COVID-19 pandemic and (2) identify factors that positively and/or negatively contributed to the subsequent mental and emotional health of nurses responding during the COVID-19 pandemic. From July to September 2022, interview data were collected from 19 nurses working in designated COVID-19 units or intensive care units between March 2020 and March 2022 in three hospitals in West Palm Beach, Broward, and Miami-Dade counties in Florida. Based on the data collected, five themes were identified: Theme #1: Nurses Experienced Mental and Emotional Trauma During the COVID-19 Pandemic Theme #2: Nurses Felt Ill-Equipped During the COVID-19 Pandemic Theme #3: Nurses Felt Undervalued During the COVID-19 Pandemic Theme #4: Factors That Contributed to Mental and Emotional Trauma in Nurses Theme #5: Factors That Safeguarded Nurses From Mental and Emotional Trauma Recommendations were provided for organizational-level interventions to mitigate adverse mental and emotional effects and promote the healthy well-being of frontline healthcare workers. Keywords: COVID-19, healthcare workers, nurses, mental health, emotional health, trauma

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN ANALYSIS OF THE CHALLENGES FACED BY NOVICE MUSIC EDUCATORS DURING THEIR COLLEGIATE EDUCATION AND EARLY IN-SERVICE YEARS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Attrition, In-service teachers, Preservice teachers, Turnover

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to analyze the challenges faced by novice music educators during their collegiate education and early in-service years as professional educators. The specific research questions that guided this study included: (a) What are some common problematic themes experienced between novice music educators as they navigated the early years of teaching? (b) How prepared did participants feel when transitioning to the professional field, and what factors of their preservice education were most/least valued during the transition? (c) What skills or values (musical or non-musical) did participants contribute any of their self- proclaimed success to as a music educator? Additional research questions later asked during two interviews included: (d) What impact did the participants’ mentor teachers have on their identities as novice music educators, specifically if their mentor teachers did not teach music? (e) What are three strongly held beliefs or teaching strategies participants felt were absolutely vital to transitioning to the professional field? (f) What have participants done to make their experiences as music educators more fulfilling, especially when dealing with COVID-19 restrictions and regulations? A literature review was completed to further explore this study’s rationales and framework. The literature review outlined the issues that past and current pre-service educators and novice in-service educators have encountered during their collegiate educations and professional careers. In addition to these issues, the review of literature also defined and gave examples of the effects of teacher attrition and turnover. Specifically, the issues that have most heavily impacted early-career attrition and turnover were discussed. Additionally, novice music educators and their pre-service experiences were especially highlighted and discussed. Data from this study were collected from a web based survey that was distributed through convenience and snowball sampling and through the Florida Music Education Association’s (FMEA) online mail-out. Due to the nature of these distribution strategies, a completion percentage was not calculated. Moreover, over the total number of participants that began the web based survey (N = 107), only approximately seventy-eight participants completed it in its entirety. Additionally, two interviews were completed to add a qualitative and exploratory perspective on the issues faced by pre-service students and novice in-service professionals. Data from the web based survey suggested that many issues such as poor administrative support, unruly student behavior, overwhelming professional duties, and other problematic themes cited in past literature are still pressing issues within the professional field. Additionally, almost half (47.78%) of the participants felt only somewhat prepared to enter the professional field and about a third (32.22%) of the participants were unsure if they were or felt they were not prepared to enter the professional field. Moreover, 60% of the participants cited they were concerned with how well they were performing their duties during their novice years of teaching, with 21% of the participants claiming they would likely leave the professional field before their fifth year of teaching. Fortunately, the participants had a lot of advice to offer in terms of coping strategies for success, both personally and successfully, as music educators. The interview portions, though short, offered valuable insights into the minds of two young music educators. While some of professional beliefs may differ slightly, the impact of their non-music teacher mentor during their early-career and identity development was the same. Non-music mentor teachers, though respected, do not hold the same value as seasoned music teachers do to young music educators. COVID-19 did not greatly impact either of these participants classrooms or day-to-day job duties.Overall, the issues faced by pre-service and in-service music educators seemed to have not changed drastically over the past several decades of modernization in the United States. While this thesis hoped to expand on past research and emphasize the troubles of the past and present, more should be done to alleviate the problems too many teachers face across the country. Otherwise, the current trends suggest that the staggering percentage of teachers already leaving the field may continue to rise, leaving even more vacancies in schools across the United States. Further results and implications are discussed within the paper.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE PROCEDURES AND CONSIDERATIONS FOR CREATING PERFORMANCE EDITIONS OF J.S. BACH’S SONATAS AND PARTITAS FOR SOLO VIOLIN FOR THE TENOR, BASS, AND ALTO TROMBONES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: J.S. Bach’s Sonatas and Partitas for Solo Violin (BWV 1001-1006) are considered some of the most important solos for violin in the repertoire. Bach overcame compositional and technical feats with his solos, writing complex, polyphonic music for a single solo instrument. These pieces are used both on the performance stage and in the private lessons studio, as they demand extreme musical and technical virtuosity that challenge even the most experienced violinists. However, the pieces’ benefits are universal to all musicians, regardless of instrument. For trombonists, transcriptions of these sonatas and partitas would add new repertoire to the repository of transcriptions and present unique challenges. This document details the basic methodology used to create performance editions of Bach’s sonatas and partitas for the tenor, bass, and alto trombones. The transcription process also elicits several concerns for transcribing string music for the trombone, for the violin can play multiple notes simultaneously while the trombone can only play a single note at a time. These concerns are addressed with various examples of solutions regarding the treatment of multiple stops and baroque ornaments. Additional details are included in the performance editions, such as tempi markings, practice suggestions, and listening recommendations, to facilitate authentic, well-informed performances of Bach’s sonatas and partitas.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Student Leadership in High School Marching Bands: A Descriptive Study

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to investigate several factors related to student leadership in high school marching bands. Specifically, the study investigated the process marching band directors used to select student leaders, what qualities marching band directors searched for in student leaders, what type of leadership training marching band directors provided for their students, and whether there was a difference in the responses between directors of competitive marching bands and non-competitive marching bands. Participants (N = 47) for this study were high school marching band directors in the southeastern United States who completed a web-based survey using Qualtrics.Participants most frequently used interviews (n = 39, 83.0%) and auditions (n = 33, 70.2%) in their student leader selection process. Most participants (n = 40, 85.1%) stated that they looked for different qualities in the students they chose to be drum majors versus those they chose to fill other leadership roles (e.g., section leaders). For drum majors, most participants prioritized natural leaders, dependable people, good musicians, and basic conducting skills. For other leadership positions, participants valued dependable people, good musicians, and people with leadership personalities. Most participants (n = 42, 89.4%) provided leadership training to their students, and discussion-based activities were the main type of training activities. There were no statistically significant differences in the responses of competitive marching band directors and non-competitive marching band directors. Results of this study provide a descriptive profile of marching band directors’ selection processes for student leaders. Implications of these findings and suggestions for future research are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INFORMAL LEARNING IN THE WORKPLACE: A STUDY OF A MUNICIPAL UTILITY IN THE SOUTHEAST

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: employee learning, Informal Learning, Informal learning behaviors, Workplace learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Employees engage in informal learning to solve a workplace problem and to gain knowledge at the time the need arises without waiting to attend a scheduled training session (Jacobs & Park, 2009; Livingstone, 1999; Schugurensky, 2000; Schürmann & Beausaert, 2016)￼ The definition employed in this study is the self-guided pursuit of knowledge, as an intentional (explicit) behavior, when the employee is cognizant of the learning while it is taking place. The organization of study was a municipal (government) utility organization in the southeast United States with combination of onsite and remote office staff, and skilled field/plant workers. The purpose of the study was to examine employees’ informal learning behaviors (ILBs) and tools that support their job performance, and to explain why they used those informal learning strategies and tools for their job performance. 172 employees completed a questionnaire reporting on their frequency of use of the following ILBs: talking with others, observing others, searching the internet, using job aids, using social media, reviewing policies and procedures, manuals, or standards, participating in coaching/mentoring, using shared materials, resources, and knowledge, using resources from professional organizations, and engaging in trial and error. Interviews with 10 employees representing both office and field employees, explained why employees engaged in ILBs and tools at work. Employees responded to the survey and the findings revealed that nine out of the ten strategies were currently being used by 70% or more of the respondents. Results also show that five out of the eight informal learning tools listed on the questionnaire were being used by 70% or more of the respondents. While office and field workers ILBs and tools usage results were similar, their explanations of their specific work context revealed some important points for the organization to consider. Workers in the field could benefit from access to organizational information and applications on their mobile device because the nature of field work required them to learn on-the-go. Other unique work environments, such as remote office workers, depended on reliable access to collaboration tools and videoconferencing. The findings can help this organization and others provide a work environment that encourages ILBs and supports their employees’ job performance by providing necessary resources and tools for informal learning.

DISS_description.DISS_title: El uso de narrativas, discursos, manifestaciones públicas y propaganda para la construcción de espacios antisistémicos en la Argentina desde el siglo XIX.
DISS_description.DISS_supp_title: The use of narratives, discourses, public demonstrations, and propaganda for the construction of antisystemic spaces in Argentina since the 19th century.

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: discurso, lucha discursiva, movimientos sociales, Piqueteros, productos culturales, Protesta

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: En esta disertación propongo que los movimientos de protesta social que han estado presentes desde la independencia argentina parten de la desigualdad social y son parte esencial de las reivindicaciones para lograr el bienestar general. Así, existen evidencias históricas de que estos movimientos han logrado reformas sociales a favor del espacio subalterno en Argentina, como, por ejemplo, la ley del trabajo de 1905 o la creación de distintos centros educativos, como la Universidad Arturo Jauretche en 2009. La motivación de mi tesis está dirigida a llenar el vacío en la investigación sobre los orígenes del movimiento de protesta, su complejidad, sus procesos dinámicos y sus logros. Mi aporte, a este trabajo, es la examinación del discurso del movimiento en dos ámbitos: el acto de protesta pública, y a través de productos culturales como la literatura, la propaganda en imágenes gráficas estáticas, el cine y otros. El marco temporal en este trabajo incluye los tiempos de la Revolución de Mayo de 1810 hasta el presente. Mi análisis ahonda en los orígenes, intenciones y prácticas de la protesta y promoción ideológica, que apuntan a lograr soluciones políticas. Al recorrer este estudio he observado la línea que conecta las distintas expresiones de protesta, desde la época de Rosas, pasando por la generación del 37, los inmigrantes, el peronismo, los movimientos armados, y otros grupos subalternos, hasta la presentación de los piqueteros. Para relacionar la genealogía de este trabajo con la lucha discursiva, entendida como la confrontación entre dos o más discursos, para convencer al individuo de adoptar una posición política, utilicé ideas de teóricos como Michel Foucault, Louis Althusser, Stuart Hall, Othón Téllez, Ana Lucia Magrini y Antonio Gramsci, entre otros, sobre el origen de los productos culturales, la comunicación narrativa, el discurso y la hegemonía cultural presentes a lo largo de los capítulos.Los capítulos 1 y 2 demuestran cómo el gobierno de Rosas promovió la violencia, la persecución, la tortura y la muerte, y cómo tras la caída de Rosas aumentó la explotación de la clase obrera por parte del poder hegemónico. Además, exploro críticamente cómo llegó Perón al poder en 1946, que fue una gran victoria de la lucha obrera demostrada en los beneficios obtenidos. Asimismo, esta unidad examina por qué surgieron movimientos armados que realizaron protestas contra el espacio hegemónico. En los capítulos 3 y 4, investigo cómo, desde 1983 hasta la actualidad, se iniciaron los piquetes contra las empresas de capital extranjero, al tiempo que se creaban instituciones educativas para fortalecer el control ideológico desde el Estado. También destaco cómo diversas expresiones culturales potenciaron la efectividad de las acciones piqueteras, como armas antisistémicas. Finalmente, las observaciones y análisis críticos realizados en los capítulos anteriores han revelado ciertas situaciones y prácticas que no permiten el avance de la democracia en Argentina. Debido a esta carencia, los grupos subalternos aparecen para pelear, a través de la protesta, por el acceso al poder de decisión del país. La evidencia fehaciente de la efectividad de estas acciones de protesta está resultando en una mayor justicia social para los grupos excluidos de la base política.

DISS_supp_abstract.DISS_para: In this dissertation, I propose that the social protest movements that have been present since Argentine independence stem from social inequality and are an essential part of claims to achieve general welfare. So, there is historical evidence that these movements have achieved social reforms in favor of the subaltern space in Argentina, such as, for example, the labor law of 1905 or the creation of different educational centers, such as the Arturo Jauretche University in 2009. The motivation of my dissertation is aimed at filling the gap in research regarding the origins of the protest movement, its complexity, its dynamic processes, and its achievements. My contribution, to this work, is the examination of the discourse of the movement in two areas: the act of public protest, and through cultural products such as literature, propaganda in graphic static images, cinema, and others. The time frame in this work includes the times of the May Revolution of 1810 to the present. My analysis delves into the origins, intentions, and practices of protest and ideological promotion, which aim to achieve political solutions. When going through this study, I have observed the line that connects the different expressions of protest, from the time of Rosas, through the generation of 37, immigrants, Peronism, armed movements, and other subaltern groups, until the presentation of the piqueteros. To relate the genealogy of this work with the discursive struggle, understood as the confrontation between two or more discourses, to convince the individual to adopt a political position, I used ideas from theorists such as Michel Foucault, Louis Althusser, Stuart Hall, Othón Téllez, Ana Lucia Magrini, and Antonio Gramsci among others concerning the origin of cultural products, narrative communication, discourse, and cultural hegemony present through the chapters. Chapters 1 and 2 demonstrate how the Rosas government promoted violence, persecution, torture, and death, and how after the fall of Rosas the exploitation of the working class by the hegemonic power increased. Furthermore, I critically explore how Perón came to power in 1946, which was a great victory for the workers' struggle demonstrated in the benefits obtained. Also, this unit examines why armed movements arose, which carried out protests against the hegemonic space. In chapters 3 and 4, I investigate how, from 1983 to the present, the pickets against foreign capital companies began, while educational institutions were created to strengthen ideological control from the State. I also highlight how a variety of cultural expressions strengthened the effectiveness of piquetero actions, as anti-systemic weapons. Finally, the observations and critical analyzes carried out in the previous chapters have revealed certain situations and practices that do not allow the advancement of democracy in Argentina. Due to this lack, subaltern groups appear to battle, through protest, for access to the decision-making power of the country. Reliable evidence of the effectiveness of these protest actions is resulting in greater social justice for groups excluded from the political base.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A CASE STUDY OF BEGINNING TEACHERS' BURNOUT AND SCHOOL CONDITIONS IN A CAREER AND TECHNICAL HIGH SCHOOL

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Beginning Teacher, Burnout, Experience, School Conditions, Stress, Support

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The researcher focused on beginning teachers in Career and Education Technical high schools. Great proportions of new teachers exit the profession, and thus the aim of this study is to understand the school-related conditions that cause teacher burnout for new teachers entering the field in this school context. This project is a qualitative case study. For the case study, 11 participants were recruited to share their experiences as a beginning teacher. In order to be considered a beginning teacher, the participants must have had between zero to five years of teaching experience. The semi-structured interviews took place via Microsoft Teams Meeting. From the interviews, the researcher found that seven out of 11 beginning teachers in this study expressed a high or medium level of burnout. These teachers expressed at least one of the three symptoms associated with burnout—emotional exhaustion, depersonalization or reduced personal accomplishment. All of the teachers with burnout described excessive workload as a major school condition contributing to burnout. Three teachers with a high level of burnout identified students’ classroom behaviors to be the major condition contributing to burnout, but excessive workload was still a contributing condition in their experience. Each beginning teacher with either a high, or medium level of burnout did not perceive their administration’s support as a tool that reduces stress. As a matter of fact, in each case, the beginning teachers had a low connectedness with their principal. Four teachers with a medium level of burnout preferred a colleague to be their first point of support over an administrator. One of the four recommendations from this study is to identify beginning teachers who are struggling with classroom management and assign either an academic coach, support staff, or peer teacher to assist the teacher with improvement, development, and burnout.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MEDIEVALISM IN AMERICAN POPULAR CULTURE: TH LEGEND OF ZELDA AND ESCAPIST FANTASY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: American Popular Culture, Medievalism, Nintendo, The Legend of Zelda, Zelda

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Legend of Zelda is a popular videogame series developed by Nintendo. It is based in the genre of medieval fantasy, specifically sword and sorcery. However, in modern popular culture, the medieval fantasy genre rarely has any attachment to the actual Middle Ages, Zelda is no different. Instead, the Zelda series exists as a post-modern medievalism. A post-modern medievalism, for the purposes of this study, is a work of popular culture that fans recognize as “medieval” in modernity but has no intended connection to the real medieval past. Instead, they focus on an attachment to other works of medieval fantasy, especially Tolkien, to fit into modern perceptions of the medieval genre.

This work explores games within the Legend of Zelda series, using music as a case study. This case study on music further extends into the fandom associated with the series. Many fans engage with the series’ music both within and outside the context of the virtual world that these games create. It is my contention that the games themselves create an atmosphere of post-modern medieval fantasy through their graphics, music, and in-game features that gesture towards the genre. Some of these features are swords, shields, castles, and magic. Fans are also invested in the music of the series, one of the key ways that the games build their medieval atmosphere alongside their graphics and imagery. Often, they will continue to listen to the official musical tracks of the games as a way to figuratively return to their childhood, a nostalgic undertaking. However, the musical cues found in newer entries to the series pay homage to earlier titles while also allowing fans to escape into a fantasy atmosphere. Breath of the Wild is an exceptionally successful title, focusing on ambient sounds that allow a player to fully immerse themselves into the natural surroundings that compose the majority of the game’s virtual landscape. However, these ambient sounds are often broken by music associated with the rampaging, destructive technology that players must combat to save the kingdom.

Beyond the games, fans also engage in their own reorchestrations of official tracks. In some instances, these reorchestrations are performed in costume and posted online for other fans to see. My argument here also incorporates the success of this genre of fan performance, and how both the actors and actresses within these works are able to bring that virtual, pseudo medieval world into our own natural world. Fans respond positively to both the theming of these videos and to the reimagining of tracks from the games of their childhood. These performances, and their positive reception amongst fans, add a sense of realism to the otherwise imaginary environments created in this sword and sorcery series of videogames.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Ultrahigh Resolution Dissolved Organic Matter Characterization Reveals Distinct Permafrost Characteristics on the Peel Plateau, Canada

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Carbon, Permafrost, Thermokarst

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Arctic is warming at a rate twice that of other global ecosystems and changing climate conditions in the Arctic are mobilizing long frozen permafrost stores of organic carbon. In regions of extensive ground ice, thawing permafrost can cause land subsidence, and the creation of thermokarst features. The Peel Plateau, Northwest Territories, Canada has extensive thermokarst features exposing early Holocene age paleo-thaw layers and Pleistocene age glaciogenic material deposited by the Laurentide Ice Sheet. This study aimed to see if unique permafrost thermokarst inputs could be readily observed in streams across six diverse thermokarst features via optical and ultrahigh-resolution mass spectrometry. Samples from within thermokarst slump features, and downstream of thermokarst inputs exhibited higher dissolved organic carbon concentrations and lower aromaticity as evidenced by optical parameters (e.g. declining SUVA254, increasing S275-295) and FT-ICR MS metrics (e.g. lower AImod and nominal oxidation state of carbon) versus upstream of thermokarst inputs. Increases in the relative abundances of assigned heteroatomic molecular formulae (e.g. CHON, CHOS, CHONS) were also greater within and downstream of thermokarst features. The unique molecular formulae present in permafrost thermokarst inputs were determined (n=1,844) and subsequently tracked downstream. These permafrost marker formulae were enriched in aliphatics and H/C as well as heteroatoms and exhibited low aromaticity. A portion of the unique molecular signatures persisted downstream, highlighting the potential to not only assess thermokarst inputs but also to follow these inputs and their fate downstream throughout the aquatic network.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TOWARDS A BELOVED COMMUNITY: THE ROLE OF MUSIC AND MULTIMEDIA AT THE UNITARIAN UNIVERSALIST CHURCH OF TALLAHASSEE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: BIPOC, Care Ethics, Congregational Study, LGTBTQ+, Musicology, Unitarian Universalism

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this thesis, I argue that the Unitarian Universalist Church of Tallahassee (UUCT) creates and uses music and multimedia to create spaces of acceptance, care, and inclusion for LGBTQ+ and BIPOC members as stated in their goal to be a “Beloved Community.” In this Beloved Community, the church has voiced its desire to create a safe and welcome space for those in disenfranchised minority groups, namely LGBTQ+ and BIPOC members. This study features analysis and examination from my nearly yearlong ethnographic research during a particular window of UUCT’s history between their re-opening after COVID-19 and the re-opening of their choir program. Along with ethnography, I use concepts and theories from Queer studies, Black studies, psychology, sociology, and musicology. Core to this study is Nathan Myrick’s “care ethics,” which underscores the meaning and influence on music in congregational worship. I use care ethics to explain the happenings on music performed in services at UUCT, as well as multimedia that is used to support UUCT’s political and inclusive goals. In this I expand Myrick’s care ethics to multimedia as well as denominations outside of Christianity. I also explore the highly nuanced and multifaceted nature of UUCT’s congregation, reflecting upon the tensions that lie under the surface of a mainly White and older community who wish to be “all-inclusive and welcoming.” In conclusion, sections of writing, photographs, and video are included to give space for my conversation partners own voices.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Tongueless Mourning: Visual-Material Rhetoric in Victorian Grief Rituals

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Grief, Material, Mourning, Photography, Victorian, Visual

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Despite the prevalence of mourning rituals across cultures and time, not much work focusing on the visual-material practices has been done within the field of rhetorical studies, which, up until the 1970s, focused almost entirely on the discursive. This limited scope overlooks the importance of nondiscursive expressions of sorrow. This thesis sheds light on the underserved visual-material mourning rhetorics through analysis of three different mourning photographs from the Victorian era: a daguerreotype, an ambrotype, and a silver gelatin print. The research questions guiding this inquiry include the following: first, how did photography operate as a visual expression of grief in the Victorian era, and second, how did photography function as a material expression of grief? In addressing these questions, this research uncovered the varied ways the photographs functioned rhetorically during the Victorian Era in the United States to assuage pain through visual and material strategies. To begin, one photograph relied on visually eulogizing the deceased’s character through phrenological and physiognomic display; another invited the viewer into doubly perceiving a child in his final portrait as both alive and dead; and, finally, a third evoked Christian iconography of angels and the Madonna to portray the deceased as peacefully existing in heaven. Each palliated grief through specific configurations of image content. Second, insights derived from an analysis of the photographs’ materiality included the unique way the mirror-like surface of a daguerreotype reflects a mourner’s likeness alongside the image of their loved one while the small size of the photograph promoted mobile use; the ambrotype featured the haptic sensation that accompanies holding a physical object that represents a deceased loved one and thus fostered the ability to pick up or set down the memory and pain associated with it; the silver gelatin print from 1910 crafted a familial and communal memory by emphasizing display of the departed, a materiality informed by the universal trauma and mass death experienced in the American Civil War. Finally, the study uncovered the inextricable link between the visual and material in mourning rhetorics, illuminating the difficulty of separating the visual elements from the material elements when analyzing these photographic objects. The visual and the material features of these photographs inform and are informed by one another, providing important context, and increasing the impact of both elements. If the two were divorced, a deceased woman would be without her name or relationship to the mourner, information provided by the note pinned to the padded case housing her photograph; a mother would be unable to hold her child’s photograph in her hands while studying a face she would otherwise never be able to look upon again; and a visually stunning image showcasing a child’s celestial journey might be overlooked as just a pretty picture of individual sorrow. Ultimately, this study illuminated the immense influence of visual-material rhetorics of mourning in the Victorian era in the United States, highlighting the importance of such rhetorics to the discipline and thus the need to expand study beyond the three images featured in this work.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Stochastic Liquidity in the Kyle-Back Model

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Kyle-Back model for insider trading describes how insiders behave in the presence of access to privileged information. We introduce stochastic liquidity into the Kyle-Back model, allowing for times of high and low volatility like in real markets and construct and prove an equilibrium in this environment. The key insight of this work is that in the equilibrium, the price is set not based on order flow directly, but an adjusted version of such which weights trades based on the liquidity at the time of transaction. The work is extension of \cite{CDF}, which considered and answered the same extension but only in the special case of a normally distributed final asset price. We find in particular with a log-normal price distribution that the log-return up to maturity at is Gaussian for any given scenario of noise-trading volatility even though the price process itself has stochastic volatility.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Experiences of Third Culture Kids in International Schools: Effects on Identity Development and Sense of Belonging

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Despite the growing number of international schools around the globe, little is done to support the highly mobile Third Culture Kid (TCK) populations in these schools. While experiencing exciting lives, TCKs have difficulty developing their individual identities and sense of belonging in communities. Problems surrounding identity and belonging can lead to depression, restlessness, and an inability to make decisions in TCKs ( Lijadi & Van Schalkwyk, 2017; Nette, 2017; Polluck & Van Reken, 2017). TCKs are often withdrawn in international schools because they are dealing with loss every time they move (Fail et al. 2004). While previous research has studied adult TCKs, these issues surrounding identity occur in the elementary years. TCKs, currently are mostly the minority in international schools due to increased interest in Western Education in host countries. This sometimes leads to the further isolation of TCKs in schools. This current trend is reflected in the Taiwan international school where I conducted my research. In this qualitative study, I used interviews with and observations of international educators who had the ability to provide observations of their TCK students. I explored how TCKs develop their sense of identity and belonging in international classrooms as well as observable traits of TCKs in the international school community. A thematic analysis generated six themes: Multiple Influences Create Confusion Concerning Personal Identity; Family Identity Outweighs Individual Identity; Family Adaptability Affects Student Adaptability; Mature and Adaptable; Outgoing Yet Comfortable Being Independent. TCKs are unaware of how much their multiple moves have on their sense of home and identity. As a result of the different cultural influences, they are unsure of where “home” is. This issue is further exacerbated by different parent nationalities, minority races, and gender. Identity for elementary TCKs is usually represented superficially by sports teams, colleges, and food. However, participants believed this was because of family preferences rather than ones from individual students. Participants also explored the fact that a TCKs comfortability in the classroom is directly related to the family’s ability to adapt to their new community. Some families have more supports than others due to the parent’s jobs, while some are left to navigate their new community on their own. Participants believe that TCKs are comfortable navigating new situations and have a better developed global perspective than their monoculture peers. This causes TCKs to often be more mature than their peers and leads them to seek out validation and acceptance from adults. Participants also observed that TCKs are outgoing and can work with any of their peers. While they are personable, they tend to stay removed from their peers and often prefer individual activities. Participants perceive this to be a result of having to leave friends behind in the past or taking their time to figure out a new school culture.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DAILY CONSUMPTION OF PRUNES AND CARDIOVASCULAR HEALTH IN OLDER MEN

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: aging men, blood lipids, CVD, inflammation, oxidative stress, prune

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a major public health challenge and the leading cause of death and disability worldwide. Atherosclerosis, a primary underlying cause of CVD, results from oxidative stress, chronic inflammation, and excess low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL) accumulation. Dietary patterns with regular fruit and vegetable consumption are associated with multiple health advantages, including cardiovascular benefits. Foods high in phytonutrients and fiber have been associated with improving chronic inflammation, vascular function, and circulating cholesterol levels. Prunes (dried plums, Prunus domestica L.) are a nutritious food with bioactive components such as polyphenolic compounds and soluble fiber, which are associated with improved cardiovascular health. The purpose of this study was to investigate the cardioprotective effects of prune supplementation and determine the extent to which daily consumption influences blood lipids, oxidative stress, chronic inflammation, and vascular function in aging men. Sixty-two healthy men aged 55 to 80 years old, with moderate bone loss, were included in the parent study. Participants were randomized into one of three treatment groups: 100g/day prune, 50g/day prune, or control (no prunes) and consumed a daily multivitamin containing 450mg calcium and 800 IU vitamin D3. Data were collected at baseline, 3-month, and 6-month timepoints and included fasting blood draw, anthropometrics, 3-day food log, physical activity questionnaire, and DXA scan preformed to measure bone mineral density. Data and blood samples from 56 participants were included in the current study, per protocol. Serum samples were analyzed for lipid concentrations including total cholesterol (TC), low and very low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-c, VLDL-c), triglycerides (TG), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-c), and TC-HDL ratio. Plasma samples were analyzed for lipid hydroperoxide (LOOH), a biomarker of oxidative stress, and proinflammatory biomarkers high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α). With 6 months of daily prune consumption, no significant changes were observed in TC, LDL-c, non-HDL-c, or TC-HDL ratio. Significant increases were observed for HDL-c from 3-month to 6-month timepoints (P=0.015), in all groups. Both VLDL-c and TG increased significantly (P=0.003) with 50g prune dose at 6 months, compared to baseline. No significant changes in CRP or TNF-α were observed. LOOH levels significantly improved with 50g dose at 3 months and 100g dose at 6 months, each compared to baseline. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) was improved at 3 months, compared to baseline, in all groups; however, no significant improvements were seen in SBP with either 50g or 100g prune dose. Findings from this study suggest that daily consumption of 50g to 100g of prunes for a period of 6 months does not significantly influence cardiovascular risk factors in healthy aging men, compared to control.

DISS_description.DISS_title: FIBRONECTIN REGULATES ACTIVATION OF CONTRACTILITY, YAP, AND NF-κB IN INTERVERTEBRAL DISC CELLS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Intervertebral disc degeneration involves breakdown of the discs of the spine due to genetics, ageing or faulty mechanical loading. As part of the progression of the disease, nucleus pulposus cells lose their phenotypic characteristics, inducing inflammation and extracellular matrix alterations. Disc homeostasis is critical for normal disc function and understanding the mechanisms of homeostasis will aid in the development of new approaches for the treatment of degenerative discs. This homeostasis is controlled by resident cells, which sense and respond to mechanical cues that influence tissue remodeling and maintenance. Fibronectin is one extracellular matrix molecule that has been shown to be upregulated in disc degeneration and plays an important role in the progression of a variety of fibrotic diseases. Fragments of fibronectin have also long been associated with both osteoarthritis and disc degeneration. Thus, fibronectin is a potential regulator of disc degeneration, and potential target for treating disc degeneration at the cellular and molecular level. The goal of this work was to test the effects of fibronectin on disc cell phenotype, mechanosensing, and inflammatory signaling. We identify that fibronectin increases the activation of cellular contractility, the mechanosensitive transcription factor YAP, and the inflammatory transcription factor NF-κB. This results in decreased production and expression of proteoglycans, which are required to maintain healthy disc function. Understanding the role of fibronectin, and its potential as a therapeutic target, could provide new approaches for preventing or reversing disc degeneration.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Understanding the Implementation of Culturally Relevant Education: Closing the Opportunity Gap

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: AVID, Culturally Relevant Education, Opportunity Gap, qualitative

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation investigated teachers’ perception and use of culturally relevant teaching by exploring how teachers define and incorporate it into their classrooms. Many researchers in education have explored the benefits of using culturally relevant teaching within the classroom to enhance student learning. Researchers have found that the greatest impact on student academic success happens when teachers activate and utilize a student's shallow and deep levels of culture. However, not much research has been done regarding how teachers perceive and incorporate culturally relevant teaching within their classrooms. This work contributes to the literature on culturally relevant pedagogy by exploring teachers’ views and uses of culturally relevant teaching within their own classrooms. Data comes from in-depth interviews with eight elementary teachers serving in schools with high populations of historically marginalized groups of students. Transcripts of teacher interviews were analyzed using two coding cycles in which a priori coding and open coding took place. The findings reveal that teachers have a positive view and strong understanding of being culturally relevant educators. Teachers saw culturally relevant teaching as a best practice to be implemented within their classroom that has many benefits to its use with students. Teachers expressed their desire to receive additional training centered around culturally relevant teaching. The findings also showed that when teachers spoke on how culturally relevant teaching is implemented within their classrooms, they did so by expressing how they activate students' shallow and deep levels of culture. Teachers stressed the importance of building safe environments and relationships with students by employing culturally relevant teaching to learn about student beliefs, home life, and culture. Very few examples of culturally relevant teaching are mentioned at the surface level of culture. Most mentions, in fact, that were surface-level culture were only in the process of saying that culturally relevant teaching is much deeper than holidays, music, and appearance.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PHOTOPRODUCTION OF THE $\eta\pi^0$ SYSTEM OFF A PROTON TARGET AT $E_{\gamma}$ = 8.5 GEV

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: hybrid mesons, partial wave analysis, QCD, regge theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The $\eta \pi$ decay channel is one of the ``golden channels'' to search for the $\pi_1$ and other spin-exotic mesons. These exotic states show up as odd partial waves in the decay of the $\eta\pi$ system. Searching for this resonance requires a detailed understanding of the nearby $a_2(1320)$ meson and necessitates a characterization of the double Reggeon exchange process that can mimic exotic signatures.

The first measurement of the differential photoproduction cross section, $d\sigma/dt$, of the $a_2(1320)$ meson at photon beam energies of $8.2-8.8$\,GeV and in the four-momentum transfer range of 0.1 to 1.0\,GeV$^2$ is performed. A full partial wave analysis is performed in the $\eta\pi^0$ invariant mass region around 1.3\,GeV$/c^2$ using amplitudes that depend on the polarization of the incoming photon beam, which allows us to separate the contributions of natural and unnatural parity exchange to the differential cross section. The partial wave analysis suggests that the $a_2(1320)$ is produced predominantly through natural exchange with total cross-section [WAITING FOR RESULT] over the measured interval.

Additionally, an analysis will be presented of the $\gamma p \to \eta \pi^0 p$ reaction beyond the resonance region, ($M(\eta\pi) > 1.6$~GeV). As input for the development of models to describe polarized photoproduction in this mass range at GlueX energies, we measure the $\Sigma$ beam asymmetry for individual $\eta$ and $\pi$ mesons for the above reaction, $\Sigma_\eta$ and $\Sigma_\pi$, as functions of several kinematic variables. These results suggest that baryon production can contribute significantly to the asymmetries. A comparison is made to measurements from $\gamma p \to \eta \pi^-\Delta^{++}$.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The (Mis)Education of Black Boys: Exploring The Black Boys: Exploring the Contributing Factors of Their Accelerated Curricular CourseDecision-Making Process

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This qualitative exploratory case study examines how low-income, Black boys, who are eligible for accelerated curricular courses at Amos P. Godby High School, decide to pursue or to not pursue accelerated coursework. The research considers what role school climate and academic self-efficacy play in that decision-making process. While there is research that examines how academic self-efficacy is associated with academic performance for Black boys, and studies that investigate the effects of the teacher-student interaction on the performance levels of Black students, there is very little research that investigates how school personnel, parental figures, and the students’ belief in their ability connect to the decision-making process from the perspective of course-eligible, low-income Black boys.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Undergraduate Music Majors' Perceptions of the Qualities and Behaviors of Effective String Orchestra Teachers

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: effective teaching, music education, string music education, string orchestra

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this paper was to examine the qualities of effective string orchestra teachers. The research questions for this study were (1) What are undergraduate music students’ perceptions of the demonstrated qualities and behaviors of string orchestra teachers? (2) Is there a significant difference in perceptions of demonstrated qualities and behaviors between males and females? (3) Is there a significant difference in perceptions of demonstrated qualities and behaviors between music education and non-music education majors?Before commencing the study, a review of literature was completed as a foundation. The review of literature highlights qualities and behaviors of effective teachers, perceptions of qualities of effective teachers, music-specific qualities of effective music teachers, as well as problems in string music education and music education overall. After a need for the study was established via this literature review, the present study began. A Qualtrics survey was sent out via convenience and snowball sampling to music education and non-music education music major undergraduate students. Due to the nature of this distribution method, a return rate could not be calculated. They had to rate the degree to which they observed nineteen specific qualities of effective teaching in five different video episodes. Results from the web-based survey suggested that undergraduate music students can identify and evaluate traits of effective music teachers. No significant differences were found between ratings of non-music education students and music education students, suggesting that teacher training is not required to be able to perceive effective teaching qualities. However, some significant differences were found between ratings of males and females. The qualities for which there were significant differences included: 1) maintains a pleasant affect; 2) demonstrates knowledge of subject matter; 3) gives clear directions, 4) motivates students well, 5) manages student behaviors, and 6) maintains a high energy level. In each of these cases, the female ratings on average were higher than the male ratings.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on the Future Workforce: The Case of Advanced Manufacturing

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Advanced Manufacturing, AI, Workforce Readiness

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study aims to examine the impact of AI on advanced manufacturing (AM) workforce. Recent progress in AI technology is at the core of AM as AI includes different technologies that will lead to the digitization of factories. While AI promises to revolutionize the field AM, little is known about how ready the AM workforce may be to make best use of AI and how best AM technicians can be readied for a career that is infused with AI. Therefore, in this research, not only I explored the AM workforce’s readiness, as expressed though industry competencies, to use AI, but also examined the areas in which AI will affect the AM workforce’s competencies, skills, and knowledge.This research applied sequential explanatory mixed-method study in which quantitative data results are considered in a qualitative phase. First, I collected and analyzed the quantitative data using natural language processing (NLP). I applied NLP to extract and compare noun, verbs, and verb-noun pairs in AI patents and the Advanced Manufacturing Competency Model. The second, qualitative, phase builds on the first, quantitative phase, and the two phases are connected in the intermediate stage in the study. For qualitative phase, expert panel review was done by conducting focus group interview. My study found that while the AI patents and the Advanced Manufacturing Competency Model do not completely topically overlap, they do reflect each other in some of the key areas such as data, device, information, and system. Also, AI technology has the potential to perform certain activities related to identify, process, and control in the field of AM industry.
