The second movement is essentially a hit list; however, it isn’t portrayed that way in the eyes of the singer. Every name is a top contributor to single-use plastic waste (Source: Minderoo Foundation’s “Plastic Waste Makers Index 2021”). Rather than shouting in anger, the singer embraces these “Capitalist Casanovas.” The goal is to create a contrast between the seriousness of the issue and the playful tone of the music, to highlight the absurdity of our reliance on single-use plastics and the culture of overconsumption that led us here.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring The Dark Side of Corporate Political Connections

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Corporate Finance, Corporate Political Activity, Dark Money, Political Connections, Political Economy, Political Scandals

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation explores the dark side of corporate political connections. Chapter One investigates the reputational spillover effect between scandal-tainted congresspersons and politically-connected firms. During the period 1992-2018, firms connected to scandal-tainted congresspersons experience a relative loss in market value and future operating and financing performance following the first media report of the scandal. The losses are greater if the congressperson does not step down from office, indicating that they are not due to broken political ties. This suggests that there is an undocumented cost of existing corporate political connections when a connected congressperson is involved in a scandal. Chapter Two utilizes three rare donor list disclosures of US dark money groups to compare exposed clandestine corporate donors to other similar non-exposed firms. The findings indicate that exposed firms experience a 2.7% increase in valuation following the first report of the donor lists. However, firms exposed as donors to a sabotaging dark money group experience a 17.8% decline in valuation and a relative loss in future operating performance. Further, firms alter their corporate political disclosure activities after these disclosure events. These findings highlight the prevalence of dark money in the US political system and the unprecedented risk associated with corporate political connections to dark money groups involved in political sabotage.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Challenging Heteronormativity: The Interplay Between Adult Attachment, Trait Mindfulness, and Sexual Outcomes Within the LGBT Community

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Heteronormativity – the implicit moral assumption that heterosexuality is the preferred or natural sexual orientation – is evident in extant family science literature and presents challenges for researchers and clinicians. The presence of heteronormativity in the field of family science limits generalizability of study findings and promotes clinical decisions based on heteronormative research when working with LGBT individuals, couples, and families. It is imperative to conduct family science research with more diverse samples in order to challenge the dominance of heteronormativity in this field and provide more effective treatment options for those within the LGBT community. Associations have been found between adult attachment, trait mindfulness, sexual desire, and sexual satisfaction separately, but these variables have not been studied in a single model. Additionally, these variables have been studied mainly with heterosexual individuals and couples, even though sexual problems – such as low sexual desire and low sexual satisfaction – can impact all individual regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity. Therefore, this study sought to explore the associations between adult attachment, trait mindfulness, sexual desire, and sexual satisfaction within the LGBT community. A sample of 303 individuals who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender completed self-report measures that studied levels of attachment anxiety and avoidance, trait mindfulness, sexual desire, and sexual satisfaction. Specifically, the study found significant inverse associations between attachment anxiety and trait mindfulness, attachment avoidance and sexual desire, as well as attachment avoidance and sexual satisfaction. Furthermore, the study found a significant indirect effect demonstrating that the association between attachment anxiety and sexual satisfaction can be accounted for by trait mindfulness. Sexual desire was not found to moderate the association between trait mindfulness and sexual satisfaction. These findings are important as studying these associations within the LGBT community is crucial in order for clinicians to provide the most appropriate and effective treatment options when working with this community. Future research could expand upon these findings by studying the specific facets of mindfulness in relation to sexual satisfaction, in order to better understand the specific mechanisms that underly this negative association. Additionally, future research could include a broader examination of the potential impact of minority stress on these associations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DISCOVERING THE EXPERIENCES OF SUPERVISORS IN A LEADERSHIP TRAINING PROGRAM

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There are over 2.5 million people employed full-time by higher education institutions across the United States, with over 1 million full-time employees at individual Research 1 (R1) higher education institutions. R1 higher education institutions employ thousands of individuals and spend at least $5 million on research expenditures. R1 higher education institutions could not function or succeed academically without the support of their employees, but unfortunately, employee job satisfaction is often ignored to focus on other immediate items like research. The purpose of this qualitative case study was to examine a leadership training program already in place at Southeastern University (SU) during the COVID-19 timeframe (January 2020 - current), while discovering the experiences and satisfaction of participants. This leadership training program has had hundreds complete the program, but there is little to nothing known about the participant's experience and satisfaction with the program. A total of fourteen program completers in a leadership position participated in a semi-structured interview lasting from 40-90 minutes. Specific characteristics were needed for the research questions to be answered successfully so participants were chosen using maximum variation purposive sampling. Constant comparative analysis was used inductively to create codes from the data. Elemental coding was used for the first-cycle method, specifically InVivo. InVivo coding allowed the ability to attune to participant perspectives and actions. The data revealed that overall participants felt like they received the resources and tools needed to lead at SU and were satisfied with the program and their learning experience. However, participants also expressed room for improvement within the program and outside of the program. Outside of the program they saw a lack of leadership skills in leaders across campus and a lack of support for the program.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Development of Computer Vision-Based Model to Identify Demolition Activities

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Activity Identification, Computer Vision, Demolition Projects

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Demolition projects are dependent on heavy equipment operations, and therefore, the success of these projects hinges on efficient heavy equipment usage. While previous studies have focused on tracking heavy equipment productivity in construction operations, such as earthwork, manually tracking the duration of heavy equipment activities can be time-consuming, labor-intensive, and prone to errors. To address this, recent studies have employed artificial intelligence-based methods to automatically identify heavy equipment activities and measure productivity in construction operations. However, unlike earthwork activities, which are relatively simple and repetitive, demolition activities are more complex and dynamic, involving structural demolition and material separation. As a result, applying existing approaches to identify demolition activities raises questions. This study proposes an automatic vision-based activity identification model that uses three-dimensional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to extract spatial and temporal features simultaneously. The model can recognize three excavator activities related to material separation, namely grabbing, swinging, and dumping, used in demolition operations. To develop the model, small-scale excavators were used to simulate real-world demolition operations while recording videos of the experiments using two cameras. The recorded video datasets were manually labeled and used to train the proposed model. Since demolition projects are not as common as construction projects, it can take a while to collect real-world data for training and validating the activity identification model. Thus, small-scale demolition simulations were used to validate the feasibility of the vision-based activity identification model, supporting its application for full-scale demolition productivity improvement. The model achieves an accuracy of 93.68% on the training dataset and 91.84% on the validation dataset. The study highlights the impact of camera placement on the model's performance, suggesting future research to optimize camera placement and configuration. Overall, this research contributes to the development of accurate and effective automated activity identification models for demolition projects. By using computer vision-based models to identify demolition activities automatically, the proposed approach is less labor-intensive, more efficient, and more accurate than traditional approaches, ultimately enhancing the productivity of demolition projects.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Numerical Modeling of Sewage Exfiltration and Solute Transport in Variably Saturated Media Using Finite Element Subsurface Flow and Transport System

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: FEFLOW, Modeling, Sewer Exfiltration

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Leaking sewer pipes can be a significant source of contaminants to soil, groundwater, and connected surface water bodies, because untreated wastewater contains nutrients, biologic pathogens, and toxic chemicals. Numerical modeling approaches are a useful tool to estimate the amount of sewer exfiltration and to assess impacts of sewer exfiltration especially for problems of a relatively large scale. This thesis research develops a numerical model using Finite Element Subsurface and Transport Flow System (FEFLOW) that simulates variably saturated flow and solute transport from a leaking sewer to a pond located near the campus of the Florida State University in Tallahassee, FL. FEFLOW is a commercial software capable of simulating heat, flow, and transport in the subsurface.This work attempts to answer the following two questions: How much sewage can potentially be leaking from the pipes of this study? How long will it take for exfiltrated sewage to enter the pond? The model-simulated exfiltration rate is between 0.02-0.08 L/s/km, which is similar in magnitude to other studies (Yang et al., 1999; Fenz et al., 2005; Morris et al., 2006). Selected solutes took 5 years to enter the closet portion pond to the exfiltrating sewer pipe. Results indicate that sewage exfiltration accounts for a loss of 4-16% of total flow in the Tallahassee sewer system. However, with solute transport taking five years to travel approximately 50 meters specific contaminants such as nutrients and biologic pathogens may not be a concern (Cordy et al., 2004; Hua et al., 2004). These results have not been evaluated using site-specific data, and thus may not represent the reality. Nonetheless, this study suggests that FEFLOW is a suitable tool for modeling sewer exfiltration problems.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORING VIRTUAL STUDENT PERCEPTIONS OF FLEXIBLE ONLINE LEARNING

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Flexibility, Flexible Online Learning, K-12, Online Learning, Virtual, Virtual School

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Most proponents of flexible online learning, and critics alike, have little more than anecdotal evidence to support their claims about the benefits or drawbacks of flexibility (Houlden & Veletsianos, 2019; Veletsianos & Houlden, 2019). This study departs from past literature that characterizes flexibility as a universal experience of online learners to explore flexibility as a relative, individual process (Houlden & Veletsianos, 2019). This exploratory, qualitative case study explores how virtual high school students at Alabama Connections Academy (ALCA) perceive and experience flexibility (of time, pace, place, and pedagogy) when learning online. Fifteen virtual students volunteered as participants and completed this study. Student participants were asked to answer open-ended journal questions about their online learning experience and then participate in 1:1 Zoom interviews about their perception of and experience with flexible online learning. By exploring individual students’ perceptions and experiences, scholars and practitioners may better understand how virtual students experience flexibility in an online learning environment. This qualitative study showed that although most student participants had overtly positive perceptions of flexibility, and many reported positive experiences, there was a range in the virtual student experience and a possible tension between some students' perception of flexibility and their experienced reality. By learning more about the virtual student experience, including what students value and/or wish to change about ALCA’s flexible learning policies, educators can craft policies to build more equitable online learning environments, with the potential to make flexibility more beneficial for, and accessible to, all virtual students.

DISS_description.DISS_title: On the Natchez Confederate Pageant

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Each Spring since 1932 residents of Natchez, Mississippi have performed a Confederate Pageant. Natchez was once the wealthiest city in the nation due to its slave trade and cotton plantations, and it has more extant antebellum architecture than any other US city. Since the Great Depression Natchez has capitalized on Lost Cause nostalgia, promoting Confederate history through tourism romantically glorifying Natchez as “where the Old South still lives.” Ladies dress in hoop skirts, offer tours of plantations, and direct youth to perform in the annual Confederate Pageant as part of “Spring Pilgrimage,” a lucrative tourist event. Climaxing with a procession by the Confederate Queen and General, the pageant reimagines the past and future nation. I use the Confederate Pageant to argue that performance sustains nationalism, that women and children are critical to the production of nationalism, and that ideologies are embedded in material practices. Performance, nationalism, and memory are interrelated embodied processes; the Confederate Pageant is a node where they intersect.

The Confederate Pageant is a ritual of surrogation that uses ideals of reproductive futurity to resurrect the Confederacy. Teleological ideals of national progress link an idealized past to an imagined future. Illustrating Lee Edelman’s concept of “reproductive futurism” the figure of the child functions politically as an idealized representation of the nation’s future. Children represent nationalist ideals of reproductive futurism in rituals of surrogation, which Joseph Roach describes as rituals where one body replaces another, in attempts to fill perceived social voids. Performances of surrogation reiterate and alter what came before: the performance is doubled yet dislocated, alike, but not identical. Surrogation functions similarly to Jacques Derrida’s supplément as an addition and replacement both extending and displacing. Performance reanimates the nation, not only as symbolic resurrection, but also evoking affect and sensation to create lived, shared experiences that create feelings of national belonging.

In Chapter One, I offer thick description detailing my observations of the performance in April 2019, then use these observations to illustrate my theoretical framework about how performance and memory, women and children, and affect and sensation function to produce nationalism. Then to provide dramaturgical context for that performance iteration, in Chapter 2 I pan to a very broad perspective situating Natchez within deep time. I offer geologic and historic context for how Natchez became the hub of plantation cotton farming, and how this impacted the US’s early development as a nation. Highlighting Mississippi authors, I note how fictional literature influenced historical narratives and memory of the past. In chapter three I use diffractive reading to discuss representations of Natchez history and the Old South. I illustrate how attitudes about race and nation linked to Natchez circulated via marketing materials, souvenirs, etc. as well as through performance. I analyze objects as performative, illustrating how they circulate ideologies, and how many forms/bodies may hold or perform memory. I highlight themes of the gestures curtsey and bow, panoramic theatrical techniques related to animation, and representations of steamboats/showboats. I also focus on silhouettes. I follow a logo that I call the “Natchez Lady Silhouette” used in tourism materials for almost a century, and relate this to developments in mass-circulated media. Finally, in chapter four, I discuss how African American residents have resisted and countered Natchez’s confederate heritage tourism by creating performances, museums, and heritage sites emphasizing their perspectives.

I take the pageant’s aesthetics as inspiration. The pageant presents the story of Natchez in vignettes of tableaux and dance, with occasional placards, minimal dialogue, and plenty of romantic, flowery imagery. I use these aesthetics (recall: aesthetic means sensation) as formal/stylistic inspiration, writing about theatre theatrically. Like the pageant, I present the story of Natchez in vignettes, silhouetted tableaux, and looping dances. While I make an academically sound argument supported by evidence, I deploy the tone of the novelist or poet. Mississippi authors have been key not just in US literature but ultimately to shaping our ideals of the nation. From William Faulkner’s Yoknapatawpha County to Jesmyn Ward’s Bois Sauvage, many cherished Mississippi authors stage their stories in imagined places, finding the essential truth of the past better remembered in fiction. Natchez offers a unique example of a place that lives materially, imaginatively, and metaphorically. I treat this text like a story, like theatre, to capture that.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Bowls are Not for Fish

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: animal welfare, awareness campaign, communication, pet freshwater fish, pet freshwater fish neglect, social identity theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The neglect of pet freshwater fish is rampant in the United States. Despite this, awareness about pet freshwater fish and the neglect they face is low among consumers. This study focused on using social identity theory in order to identify the ideal target market for an awareness campaign designed to prevent the neglect of pet freshwater fish. A survey was distributed to 214 participants (n = 214) and results were interpreted using one-way ANOVA. Findings of this study demonstrated a link between higher levels of identification with animal welfare activists and higher levels of identification with pet freshwater fish, higher levels of anger over the neglect of pet freshwater fish and higher levels of moral conviction over pet freshwater fish. These findings can be used by communications practitioners because they suggest higher levels of support towards preventing the neglect of pet freshwater fish by individuals with higher levels of identification with animal welfare activists. Because individuals with higher levels of identification with animal welfare activists can be assumed to have a lower likelihood of neglecting pet freshwater fish based on the results of this study, this study will contribute to the environmental communications field by determining that individuals with low levels of identification with animal welfare activists should be targeted with an awareness campaign to prevent the neglect of pet freshwater fish. This study will also help fill the current gap in literature surrounding pet freshwater fish neglect and communications, as it is the first of its kind to directly link pet freshwater fish neglect and communications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A MIXED METHODS APPROACH TO INVESTIGATING MUSIC TEACHER RETENTION AND ATTRITION IN ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Alternative Schools, Retention, Special Music Education, Students with Disabilities

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to examine the qualifications, preservice experiences, and factors that influence teacher retention and attrition; and identify the needs of music teachers working in alternative schools to understand the factors that lead to music teacher retention and attrition in these schools. As this was the first study to examine music teachers in alternative schools, an attempt was made to understand who these music teachers were, recognize the factors related to their retention, and understand why specific factors were essential to the participants while others were considered unimportant. A sequential-explanatory mixed methods design was used to identify those factors that lead to music teacher attrition before exploring these ideas deeper with five specific cases. The Four Capital Theory of Teacher Retention served as the foundation for this study. It organizes the factors related to teacher retention and attrition and investigates these themes through the lens of preexisting theories: (1) human capital, (2) social capital, (3) structural capital, and (4) positive psychological capital. Strand 1 was descriptive, and examined the qualifications, preservice experiences, and factors that influence teacher retention and attrition. Results from strand 1 indicated that all teachers in the study chose to teach in their schools, nearly one-third of participants had no training in working with students with exceptionalities, and social factors are of most importance for retention. The qualitative strand 2 followed, shedding light on the lived experiences of teachers who worked in exceptional centers in Florida. Here, each teacher expressed their thoughts regarding each of the factors and how they were impacted by them. Teachers also discussed desired training opportunities. Finally, strand 3 integrated information gathered during the qualitative phase of the study with data from interviews in an effort to understand how these teachers determined those factors of most importance.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE SORROW FESTIVAL: poems

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: confessional writing, grief, poetry, tallahassee, women's confessional poetry, women's literature

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Sorrow Festival is a collection of poetry rooted in the north Florida landscape; the juxtaposition of the region’s sublime subtropical beauty with its horrific storms and crawling creatures directly relates to the juxtaposition of transcendent joy and feral sorrow experienced by the post-confessional lyric speaker. Ultimately, the city of Tallahassee and the nearby Forgotten and Gulf coasts (and the wildlife specific to these places) become characters of their own that populate the pages in conversation with the narrator. In a variety of traditional, experimental, and hybrid forms, this manuscript thematically interrogates family memory, grief, sexuality, and gendered violence. Underlying the speaker’s personal revelations is the project of the “confessional” and its relationship to poetic impulse, women’s writing, sexual, political, and personal autonomy, and the social and aesthetic devaluations of these, both historically and in contemporary life. These considerations are in direct conversation with the manuscript’s setting in the American South, and the sociopolitical dynamics that complicate a woman’s place in it.

The first section of the manuscript is driven by memory and story, reflecting on the impact of domestic violence, estrangement, illness, and grief on a family lineage. The second section is composed of a long hybrid poem/lyric essay expanding on the chaotic, animalistic nature of grief as intertwined with the speaker’s understanding of partnership and sexuality. The third section situates the speaker in the present, where the uncontainable beauty and violence of the landscape mirrors the grandeurs and disasters of the speaker’s relationships with friends, family, lovers, and poetry itself. The fourth section takes an epistolary prose poem form, in which the speaker divulges further details about her family history of domestic violence as related to confession. Finally, the fifth section returns to images of Florida’s natural landscape in spring to convey a renewed—though complicated—sense of hope for the speaker. The dissertation opens with a critical introduction that aims to contextualize the creative work within a tradition of Confessional and Post-Confessional poetics, feminist literary theory, and the craft of hybrid texts in contemporary literature.

DISS_description.DISS_title: CULTURALLY SUSTAINING INSTRUCTIONAL STRATEGIES IMPLEMENTED BY DESIGNERS-BY-ASSIGNMENT IN HIGHER EDUCATION STUDENT SERVICES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: culturally sustaining instructional design, culture, designers-by-assignment, instructional design, online learning environment

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Research has recognized that a student’s culture plays a role in how they experience an online learning environment, and many higher education institutions are challenged by retaining and graduating historically underserved students identified as a “success gap”. For historically underserved students – defined in this study as students of color, first-generation college students who are the first in their families to attend college, and students from a low-income household – gaining access to, retaining in, and matriculating to post-secondary education can be a challenge. One factor to include in the assessment of the “success gap” is the increasing number of racially and ethnically diverse students, first-generation college students, and low-income students enrolling in online classes and programs. By acknowledging the presence of learners’ diverse cultural backgrounds, instructors, instructional designers, and designers-by-assignment (DBAs)—an impromptu instructional designer—can systematically incorporate cultural values throughout the design and development process. There is a growing concern from DBAs, such as faculty and student support staff in higher education, to address the success gap of diverse students through more inclusive online learning design. Since the instructional systems design field has not been able to produce a more situated framework or consistent strategies for inclusive online learning and culturally sustaining instructional strategies, this study will explore the expertise of higher education administrators who are culturally inclusive subject matter experts (SMEs) and DBAs—specifically staff who work with the Ronald E. McNair Scholars program—to identify key attributes of inclusive online learning environments and culturally sustaining instructional strategies for higher educations’ increasingly diverse student population. Since McNair Scholar staff are DBAs and SMEs in inclusive education and support of historically underserved populations, they could benefit from implementing instructional design models in their online learning environments. This exploratory multiple-case study uses the Culturally Sustaining Instructional Design model as a conceptual framework to investigate how and why DBA administrators in higher education incorporate inclusive strategies into their instructional design practices. The six major themes and culturally sustaining strategies found in the data include creating a space for authentic learning, creating access to learning materials, selecting an inclusive instructional approach, creating a network of support, clarifying expectations, and being flexible. Analysis also found that there were contextual factors and desired outcomes that influenced the DBAs’ decisions to implement culturally sustaining instructional strategies. Finally, four thematic categories were discussed by the participants when discussing how they assessed their instructional strategies: Engaging with the Feedback Loop, Observing Changes in the Scholar, Measuring the Scholar’s Learning, and Issues Identified with Assessing Effectiveness. Finally, I describe implications of my findings for each major theme found for culturally inclusive strategies: Space, Access, Instructional Approach, Network of Support, Expectations, and Flexibility. Working with first-generation college students, students from low-income backgrounds, and underrepresented minority students in higher education, McNair DBAs modeled culturally sustaining instructional strategies by making systematic decisions to implement inclusive online learning environments. This study contributes culturally sustaining strategies to the literature that are popular among McNair DBAs. Ultimately, the success gap will minimize if all online learning environments are intentionally designed for the inclusion of diverse students.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Understanding Subsynchronous Resonance using Real Time Digital Simulation and Nyquist Stability Criterion

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: subsynchronous oscillations, subsynchronous resonance

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Subsynchronous Resonance (SSR) is a unique power systems phenomenon that was relatively unknown until a 1970’s incident at the Mohave Power Station damaged two turbine-generators in the exact same segment of their shafts. This surprising outcome indicated that the mechanical properties of these shaft segments were somehow related to their failures. Unknown at the time, was that a disturbance in the electrical system created an SSR signal causing rotor torques on the shaft that coincidentally matched its natural oscillation frequency. The result was an increasing energy exchanging loop between the electrical and mechanical sides of the power system ending with shaft failure. This thesis proposes that instability issues like the Mohave case can be identified and corrected early on using an Electromagnetic Transients Program (EMTP) and the Nyquist Stability Criterion (NSC). The results prove that the Nyquist plots of the mechanical and electrical gains over the subsynchronous frequency range (0 – 60 Hz) accurately predict the shaft designs at risk of SSR by encircling the point (-1,0) on their graphs. Moreover, simulation outputs confirm that the torque waveforms exceed safe operating limits for shaft segments predicted as high-risk. The successful demonstration of this predictive process can then be developed to analyze the stability of related phenomena, such as subsynchronous oscillations (SSO), which may impact modern microgrid systems containing power converters.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UNDERSTANDING INSTRUCTIONAL LEADERSHIP IN RURAL SCHOOLS: PRINCIAPLS’ PRACTICES AND THE INFLUENCE OF CONTEXTUAL FACTORS ON THEIR ROLES AS INSTRUCTIONAL LEADERS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: instructional, leadership, principal, rural

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Principals’ experiences in rural schools often differ from that of their urban and suburban counterparts. They often experience challenges that are not only unique to their specific contexts but influence their roles as instructional leaders. With instructional leadership at the forefront of the principalship, it is important to explore how rural principals engage in the work and how they navigate the multitude of contextual factors that impact their roles. The purpose of this qualitative case study is to gain a deeper understanding of what instructional leadership looks and feels like in a rural, Title I school district in north Florida. Using Leithwood’s (2021) leadership framework to inform the study, data were collected through one-on-one, semi-structured interviews wherein participants described instructional leadership, the practices of instructional leadership that they engaged in, and what factors they identify as influencing their roles as instructional leaders. Data were analyzed using the framework to identify patterns and trends across participants. This study found that while there aren’t stark contrasts in the way rural principals described instructional leadership in comparison to the framework’s definition, it is worth noting that participants emphasized that relationships played a vital role in instructional leadership and were critical in building capacity and improving instruction. Furthermore, rural principals spent the majority of their time in the Building Relationships and Developing People Domain and Improving the Instructional Program Domain. When asked about the factors that influence their roles as instructional leaders, principals identified opportunity gaps, resource limitations, and political culture as negative influences, while the community and the availability of programs that support students and families were seen as positive influences. The implications of this study are relevant for principals, district leaders, policymakers, and researchers. Principals expressed the desire and need to have more opportunities to engage with their colleagues and in professional development. Given that principals identified barriers and supports that impact their roles, district leaders may consider examining how they can address some of the challenges while leveraging the existing systems and resources available to strengthen principals’ instructional leadership practices. At the researcher level, examining what rural-specific supports impact principals most will provide valuable insight into how rural principals can best be supported.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Audit Budget Surrogation: Substituting The Budget For Audit Risk

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Audit, Budgets, Performance Measures, Risk, Strategy, Surrogation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Prior audit research and PCAOB inspection reports provide evidence that auditors often fail to revise audit plans to effectively address new risks that are revealed during audit fieldwork. I investigate how budget performance measures contribute to this issue by increasing both auditors’ perceived and actual resource pressures. I also examine how a psychology intervention called constraint-based planning (CBP) encourages auditors to allocate their resources more effectively in an environment where audit risk is shifting. I incorporate the economic incentives and resource constraints of an audit into an experimental economics experiment to test my research questions. I find that budget performance measures cause auditors to misallocate their resources when the perceived or actual level of audit risk shifts after the creation of the budget. I also find that auditors who participate in CBP allocate their resources more effectively to an extent that they are more likely to address accounts that change in riskiness.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Representation Through Performance: A Study of Six 21st Century Works for Tuba by Women Composers

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The history of women composers has been defined by overt prejudice. However, in the 20th century that narrative began to change. By the 1950s women composers began to thrive, having their works performed worldwide and in virtually all genres. Recognition of their works has flourished, with two Pulitzer Prize winners, numerous Grammy Awards, acceptance into prestigious fellowships, and more. Their contributions to the world of music are making a noticeable impact on classical music and their works for tuba are no exception.The intent of this treatise is to be a resource of solo literature for tuba written by various women composers. The selected solo works have been chosen to represent quality literature at various difficulty levels. Two works have been chosen to highlight each difficulty level. For each work, the author identified their purpose for selection, musical form, and performance challenges. Along with the description will be suggested performance fundamentals designed to assist with key components of each piece. In addition to the selections in this paper, a more extensive list of works has been provided. Each work includes a brief biography about the composer and a difficulty rating based on the ITEA Standard Literature rubric.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Clarinet Works of Carl Vollrath

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Carl Vollrath, clarinet, Vollrath

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this treatise is to catalog the music of Carl Vollrath and further preserve his work with biographical information and accounts of those who have performed and recorded his music. This document centers around a compendium of works for solo clarinet with piano, solo clarinet with wind ensemble, and chamber music for two or three players that features the clarinet. Each entry contains the title of the work, date composed or copyrighted, titles of movements or sections and tempo markings, and sources for which recordings can be acquired. Further details include Vollrath’s inspiration for each work, and pedagogical considerations including difficulty level, range of clarinet writing, and basic form and stylistic characteristics of the composition. Future implications of this document include the creation of a web archive where information about the composer and his works can be found including this compendium. Information from this document will be presented in future publications, presentations, and lecture recitals to advocate for the composer’s works. Through these resources, Carl Vollrath’s music will become more accessible to the public.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Music therapy private practice: A business model analysis

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: A growing number of music therapists across the country own a private practice that provides music therapy services to a variety of populations. The purpose of this survey was to analyze data based on demographics of music therapy private practice owners, allocation of administrative time, and private practice business models across the United States. Music therapy business owners (N=111) responded to a nationwide survey regarding how their time was divided throughout the week and how revenue was generated for their individual practice. The results indicated that a majority of private practice owners who responded were new to the field within the past 10 years and devoted the most time during the week to direct client interactions. The results of this survey are beneficial to the field of music therapy because it warrants further discussion regarding the future of private practice.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SYSTEMATIC HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS IN UKRAINE SINCE RUSSIA’S FEBRUARY 2022 INVASION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: atrocity crimes, human rights violations, Russia, systematic, Ukraine

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This paper examines human rights violations in Ukraine, attributed to Russia and the self-proclaimed ‘republics’ of Donetsk and Luhansk. These violations include cases of arbitrary detention, enforced disappearances, torture and ill-treatment, and conflict-related sexual violence (CRSV) against vulnerable populations. Historically, Russia and the self-proclaimed ‘republics’ have failed to take accountability for their role in committing these offenses, including consistently underreporting data and not allowing human rights monitors to access detainees under their administrations. Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, systematic abuse has been executed against civilians, detainees, and prisoners of war at even greater rates. In this paper, I argue that they are systematic in nature and fit into the framework for atrocity crimes, as defined by the Rome Statute of International Criminal Court. In my literature review, I discuss prior research and reporting by international monitors, who have watched the progression of abuses taking place in Ukraine and their approach to holding those involved, accountable. Within this paper, I use the method of secondary analysis of existing data, by means of triangulation, to converge data pulled from three human rights monitors. These data are extracted from existing data published by nongovernmental organizations that launched monitoring projects in response to the Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, to document numerous, ongoing human rights violations. This thesis discusses how human rights abuses have systematically increased since the invasion, and how human rights monitors have documented them with the use of a secondary analysis of already existing data. I also discuss limitations that arise from their type of reporting and explore how triangulation trivializes missing numbers, by addressing key trends.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BETHLEHEM’S ARSENAL: BETHLEHEM STEEL CORPORATION’S MOBILIZATION IN WORLD WAR II, 1939-1945

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bethlehem, Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Johnstown, Shipbuilding, Steel Industry, World War II

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Bethlehem Steel Corporation was once America’s largest private shipbuilder and the second largest steel producer in the world. At its formation in 1904, its founder and chairman Charles M. Schwab combined the plants, mills, mines and other properties of the Bethlehem Steel Company with United States Shipbuilding Corporation to form the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. Much of the historical literature on Bethlehem Steel focuses on explaining the corporation’s downfall. Corporate publications from the wartime era underline Eugene G. Grace’s central role in how Bethlehem viewed, advertised and promoted itself to a wider audience of employees, customers, government officials and the public. This study analyzes publications from this period in the press, industry trade journals, and Bethlehem Steel’s own bulletins and announcements to explore how the corporation, its managers and its employees navigated the wartime years from 1939 through 1945. The main research question is: How did Bethlehem Steel mobilize its plants, yards and workforce in support of the American and Allied war effort during World War II? Production remained the dominant theme throughout the war: producing more steel, ships and other defense-related materials as fast as possible. Shipbuilding was Bethlehem’s most important contribution to the war effort, followed closely by its steel production. The corporation’s integrated nature was a source of strength for wartime production. Bethlehem Steel contributed an enormous amount of raw steel, munitions, fabricated steel products, naval and merchant shipping, and ship repair work in meeting the nation’s defense needs. To meet its production demands Bethlehem Steel expanded its workforce to unprecedented levels. Bethlehem’s leaders expected and demanded the loyalty of its employees. Anything less represented disloyalty to the nation’s war effort. Lastly, Bethlehem activelypromoted its public image. It portrayed itself as a patriotic, benevolent and paternalistic viii corporation, leading the charge on the front lines of America’s industrial production. Through its effort, teamwork and leadership Bethlehem promoted itself as a decisive contributor to the eventual Allied victory. Bethlehem Steel was an integrated corporation, which went beyond the physical layout and infrastructure of its steel mills and shipyards. Bethlehem also took an integrated approach to narrating its wartime history. In its published materials Bethlehem Steel Corporation emphasized its production, its steadfast loyalty to the United States and a consistently positive corporate image.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE EFFECTS OF DIGITAL AUDIO AND VIDEO QUALITY ON COLLEGIATE MUSIC STUDENTS’ RATINGS OF VOCALISTS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to determine whether differences in digital audio and video quality impact collegiate music majors’ ratings of a solo vocalist’s performance. With this purpose in mind, I developed the following research questions: 1) Do instrumental and vocal collegiate music students perceive differences in tone quality of a vocalist’s performance encoded at high and low audio and video qualities? 2) Do instrumental and vocal collegiate music students perceive differences in technique of a vocalist’s performance encoded at high and low audio and video qualities? 3) Do instrumental and vocal collegiate music students perceive differences in musicality of a vocalist’s performance encoded at high and low audio and video qualities? 4) To what extent are collegiate music students aware of differences in audio and video quality when rating a vocalist’s performance? I made a stimulus recording of a vocalist and pianist performing four verses of Cecil J. Sharp’s arrangement of The Holly and The Ivy. These four verses were then encoded at two video qualities (1080p resolution and 144p resolution) and two audio qualities (48 kHz sample rate with 24 bits of depth and 8kHz sample rate with 8 bits of depth) for a total of four possible video combinations. Participants (N = 93) watched each of the four video clips and rated the participant’s tone quality, technique, and musicality in each condition. After viewing the stimulus videos and making ratings, participants then answered the free-response question “What factors influenced your ratings?” After performing statistical analyses, I found significant main effects for audio quality in all three rating categories. Participants rated the vocalist’s tone quality, technique, and musicality higher in the high audio quality conditions than in the low audio quality conditions. I also found significant main effects for participants’ self-identified primary instrument in two of the rating categories, with instrumentalists (n = 35) rating the vocalist’s tone and technique higher overall than vocalists (n = 58) did. Additionally, there were two interactions involving participants’ ratings of the vocalist’s tone: an audio quality by primary instrument interaction and an audio quality by video quality by viewing order interaction. Instrumentalists rated tone quality higher in the high audio quality condition and lower in the low audio quality condition than vocalists did. In the three-way interaction, participants in one viewing order rated tone in the high audio and low audio recordings higher when paired with congruent video quality, even when the audio and video were of congruently low quality. I coded participants’ answers to the free-response question to analyze which factors were most cited by participants as affecting their ratings. Most participants cited either audio quality, video quality, or general recording quality as affecting their ratings. A smaller, but not insubstantial portion of the participants stated they were aware of the recording quality but did not let it influence their ratings. Taken together, this would indicate that judges will inconsistently incorporate knowledge of the quality of digital recordings when making judgements of solo vocalists. Other commonly cited factors included performer sounds and appearance. These findings have ramifications for musicians, particularly vocalists, who use both livestreamed and pre-recorded audiovisuals to share and view recordings of performances. Given the links between household income, urban-rural classification, parent education level, and other socio-economic factors and at-home internet speed, educators in particular should consider the methods by which they recommend and implement streaming in their classrooms and curricula.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Quantum Critical Regimes Around the Metal-Insulator Transition

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Metal-insulator transitions (MITs) remain one of the unresolved science problems of condensed-matter physics, which are rather general and of fundamental importance. In the vicinity of the MITs, the behavior is found to be unconventional and exotic. This complexity makes it difficult to recognize the dominant degrees of freedom, resulting in a plethora of theoretical viewpoints based on very different ideas.

First we study the transport behavior and the dielectric response near Mott Metal-Insulator transition (MIT) using the Iterative Perturbation Theory (IPT), which is exact at the atomic limit at half-filling, for the single-band Hubbard model supplemented by percolation theory. We successfully interpret the experimental observation of a colossal peak of the dielectric function near the Mott MIT in organic material $\kappa\text{-(BEDT-TTF)}_2\text{Cu}_2\text{(CN)}_3$. Our results suggest the diverging feature of dielectric response comes from percolation effects near a first-order MIT, where metallic and insulator domains present simultaneously as long as the materials have defects or impurities. Our findings suggest a similar ‘dielectric catastrophe’ in many other correlated materials and can explain previous observations that were assigned to multiferroicity or ferroelectricity.

Second we summarize both experimental and theoretical observations of the criticality around the Mott transition, in three types of systems: 2-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) in Si-MOSFE, Mott organic material ($\kappa\text{-(BEDT-TTF)}_2\text{Cu}_2\text{(CN)}_3$), and transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) moire bilayer $\text{MoTe}_2/\text{WSe}_2$. Particularly, we find robust resistivity maxima are clearly seen in all these materials. We then use dynamical mean field theory (DMFT) and 'hybrid' DMFT correspondingly to show that dielectric response can be used to identify the origin of these resistivity maxima. We find that near the MIT, it corresponds to the percolation effect within the (spatially inhomogeneous) metal-insulator phase coexistence region, where a colossal enhancement of the dielectric response has been found. Deep in the metallic phase, it signals the thermal destruction of coherent quasiparticles due to strong correlation effects, and a dramatic drop and a change of sign in the dielectric constant would be found.

Third we study the disorder dominated MIT in TMD moiré bilayer. In this material, a long-range geometric moiré pattern emerges when two atomically thin materials are misaligned or have a lattice mismatch. This drastically reduces the electronic kinetic energy, paving the way for new strongly correlated phases. We proposed a minimal theoretical model describing the interplay of interactions and disorder, which is solved at DMFT + coherent potential approximation (CPA) level. The results capture most experimental trends at almost a perfect level. We investigate the quantum criticality near MIT with a fully occupied flat band (f=2), which is found to be in a disorder-dominated regime.

Finally, we consider long-range Coulomb interaction in low band filling cases, where one expects Wigner crystallization to occur. To investigate the nontrivial electronic phases appearing away from commensurate fillings, we first used the spinless Hartree method to calculate the total free energy, and then we used DMFT and Kubo formula to obtain the transport behavior. We find that, for most fillings, an amorphous charge-ordered metallic state – the electron slush – appears in strongly correlated TMD hetero-bilayers. Our results suggest performing transport and Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM) experiments on TMD hetero-bilayers to study the interplay between doping a Wigner-Mott insulator and amorphous charge order.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The History and Pedagogy of Low Flutes

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: alto flute, bass flute, contrabass flute, Low Flutes, pedagogy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The low flute family–including the alto, bass, contralto, contrabass, subcontrabass, double contrabass, and hyperbass flutes–is experiencing an increase in instrument making, repertoire, and performance opportunities. With growing attention given to these instruments in solo, chamber, and orchestral settings, this treatise strives to examine the history and the teaching practices of low flutes. The instruments included in the discussion focus mainly on the alto, bass, and contrabass, with consideration given to the contralto, subcontrabass, double contrabass, and other bass flutes (i.e. bass in F). The testimonies and histories of professionals, past and present, are referenced in an effort to shed light on the development of alto and bass flutes, as well as other lower wind instruments. This includes recent innovations in flute design that occurred during the twenty-first century.To consider the teaching practices of low flutes, the following section of the treatise addresses the pedagogy of three prominent low flute players¬–Christine Potter, Paige Long, and Carla Rees. Through interviews conducted in 2022, information and detail is provided about their lives, first encounters with low flutes, and teaching emphases. The final chapter explores a pedagogical path of study, proposing possible courses for a graduate-level Specialized Program of Study in Low Flutes. Drawing from the information gathered in the interviews, my personal experience, and historical accounts, I propose a program and teaching materials with syllabi and outline course objectives that aim to advance low flute playing in solo and ensemble settings. Interested teachers and students may use this as a resource to understand the history of low flutes and reference pedagogical approaches for these instruments.

DISS_description.DISS_title: POWER DISTRIBUTION CABLES AND CRYOGENIC SYSTEMS FOR SUPERCONDUCTING TRANSPORT PLATFORMS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Cryogenic Dielectrics, Dielectric Cable Design, Electric Ship, Failure Modes Effects and Analysis, High Temperature Superconductors, High Voltage Cables

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Future electric transport systems will have high-power dense devices such as high-temperature superconducting (HTS) motors, generators, and power distribution cable networks. A high power density is desirable to achieve the necessary efficiency and design with space and weight requirements. The electric transport systems would reduce greenhouse emissions and have other benefits, such as reduced noise, compared to the conventional platforms that use internal combustion for propulsion. Two such applications under development are electric ships and electric aircraft. These platforms will have 30-100 MW power systems. Government agencies and industry are investing in the designs and development of component technologies.The dissertation explored the high temperature superconducting (HTS) power devices and the necessary cryogenic system designs. Part of the dissertation focused on HTS power cable designs. The thermal network modeling methodology was used to understand the implications of component failure and options to achieve resiliency. A radial architecture for the ship power distribution network was investigated to fully utilize the HTS cable technology in achieving efficiency, stability, and resiliency. Two HTS cable topologies were explored for the radial system. HTS cable ampacity being sensitive to the operating temperature, the resiliency of the cryogenic system in supporting the electrical distribution network is critical. The results of the combined electrical and cryogenic thermal models show that the cryogenic systems can support radial distribution. The models were used to map the cryogenic temperature profile of the distribution system in both normal and contingency operations involving a failure of one of the cables. The cryogenic system satisfactorily supported the increased current in the other cables to mitigate the loss of one of the cables with a manageable temperature increase of 2-3 K. The models also concluded that cryogenics does not hinder the radial distribution concept. To assess the broader question of cryogenic fuels for large transport systems, a review was performed on the opportunities and challenges of cryogenic power devices for electric aircraft and the ongoing research and development efforts. Relative merits of liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquefied natural gas (LNG) are compared in supporting the HTS and normal metal devices. The mass flow rates and fuel quantity requirements for both cryogenic fuels were simulated using thermal network models. A twin-aisle, 300-passenger aircraft with a 5.5 h flight duration was used for the models. The results show that the required masses of LH2 and LNG are 750 kg and 13,600 kg, respectively, for the cooling requirement. The corresponding volumes of LH2 and LNG are 10,000 and 30,000 L, respectively. In both cases, the estimated mass of the fuel needed for the aircraft is more than what is necessary to maintain the cryogenic environment of the power devices. It was concluded that an electric aircraft with LNG-cooled normal metal devices is feasible. However, an aircraft with HTS devices cooled with LH2 is more attractive if the ongoing R&D efforts on HTS devices and green hydrogen infrastructure are successful. The emission reductions would be substantially higher with LH2, particularly with green hydrogen produced using renewable energy sources. A coaxial superconducting gas insulated cable (SGIL) was designed, fabricated, and tested to understand the challenges in making compact cables cooled by gaseous helium (GHe). Two kinds of insulating spacers were explored to understand the effect of permittivity mismatch on the maximum electric field strength. The latest design iteration of the dipole SGIL showed promising results of sufficiently high breakdown strength. Investigations found that the cables suffer from corona discharge activity at the intended operating voltages, reducing the cables' lifespan. The major limiting factor of the design is the high electric field stress at the triple point, causing localized corona discharge activity in the gaseous cryogen trapped between the spacers. New dipole cable designs must address the high permittivity mismatch between GHe and the spacers to reduce the high field stresses. New geometries are needed to achieve desired dielectric properties while maintaining the heat transfer effectiveness and flexibility of HTS cables. Potential failure modes of HTS devices and related cryogenic systems in electric ships are analyzed to understand and plan for the necessary mitigation systems. Risk-based FMEA methodology was adopted to aid in improving the resiliency of large superconducting power distribution systems. A concurrent FMEA study of cryogenic thermal and electrical systems in an HTS power distribution network is discussed. A one-line architecture for a power distribution system was developed to identify the critical parameters needed for performing FMEA for HTS power distribution systems. The failure modes are listed to show the interdependence of the electrical and cryogenic systems. The severity and detectability of various failures were used to formulate critical redundancy and mitigation tools to design resilient power distribution systems for electric ships.

DISS_description.DISS_title: "Called to Excellence": A Diachronic Study of the Worshipscape at First Baptist Church Midway in Plant City, Florida

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Baptist, Florida, Musicology, Sacred Music, Soundscapes, Worship

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis explores the worshipscape of First Baptist Church Midway (FBC Midway), a Southern Baptist church located in Plant City, Florida. With nearly 125 years of history and worship, FBC Midway has gone through many eras of music and worship practices. My study of this Southern Baptist church’s worship history is threefold. I examine the spaces in which worship happened and continues to happen, the people who were and still are worshipping in these spaces, and the various musical styles that they have used in worship. Through a combination of archival research, ethnographic conversations, and personal reflection, I piece together a meaningful representation of this specific worshipscape and how the people who inhabited it understood its function in their lives in and outside of the church. The term “worshipscape” was coined by Adekunle Oyeniyi and is new to the field of congregational studies. Oyeniyi derived this term primarily from Michela Mari’s and Sara Poggesi’s term “servicescape” (2013). In doing so, he prioritizes the concepts of musical style and demographic appeal. The use of “worshipscape” in this thesis is adapted from this previous work, as well as R. Murray Schafer’s concept of a soundscape, to include all musical and extra-musical aspects of worship in a given church community. This fieldwork conducted at FBC Midway is a practical and multifaceted attempt at unearthing multiple layers of influential factors important to understanding its worshipscape and how it has changed over time. The difficulty in studying worshipscapes lies in attempts at holistic representation. Much like their secular counterparts, spiritual soundscapes constantly evolve and change over time. Through this study, I develop a useful theoretical and methodological framework for investigating a Christian Baptist church’s sonic worship practices from their historical formation through their present-day renditions. By employing a conglomerate of ethnomusicology, ecomusicology, sound studies, and archive studies, I juxtapose multiple influencing aspects of worship and sound into a cyclical relationship. This framework can be applied broadly to the holistic study of worshipscapes that span various religions, geographical areas, and worship practices.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Do Threats to Masculinity Predict Increased Firearm-Related Aggression in Men?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Aggression, Gun violence, Masculinity, Men, Social threat, Violence

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Men commit 86% of all gun-related homicides in the United States despite women accounting for 40% of gun ownership. Hegemonic definitions of gender indicate that traditional masculine traits, compared to traditional feminine traits, are more related to violent behaviors. The precarious manhood paradigm (Vandello et al., 2008) states that masculinity is constantly precarious. According to this paradigm, masculinity must be outwardly defended in the face of threat; the easiest way is through displays of violence and aggression. We conducted the first-ever experiment to test if high levels of trait masculinity, threat to masculinity, and their interaction predicted deadly firearm use during simulated reality scenarios depicting ambiguously dangerous situations. Undergraduate participants were 90 straight, cis-gendered men in the Southeast United States who were randomly assigned to the control group (n=45) or the masculinity threat group (n=45). Consistent with hypotheses, the masculinity threat predicted increased deadly firearm use in men with high trait masculinity, as measured by the CMNI-22 (Burns & Mahalik, 2008). Higher trait masculinity also predicted faster deadly firearm use in men whose masculinity was threatened, which was partially consistent with hypotheses. Findings suggest that threats to one’s masculinity potentiate gun violence in men with high trait masculinity.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Investigating the role of scheduled, voluntary exercise in protecting skeletal muscle against core clock and health against alcohol-induced disruptions

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: aerobic exercise, alcohol, mitochondria, molecular clock, myopathy, skeletal muscle

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The skeletal muscle clock contributes to the regulation of skeletal muscle health and function. Mutations to the muscle clock result in decreased muscle mass and strength, diminished mitochondrial health, and altered substrate metabolism in the muscle. Chronic alcohol (EtOH) ingestion disrupts components of the core molecular clock, alters mitochondrial function, and decreases muscle mass and strength. Exercise is a potent stimulator of the muscle clock, and exercise training promotes muscle and mitochondrial health. PURPOSE: In the current study, we examined the potential protective effects of scheduled, voluntary wheel running on alcohol-induced disruptions to the skeletal muscle clock and the effects of alcohol on exercise-induced muscle adaptations. METHODS: Female C57BL/6 mice were randomly assigned to one of 4 groups: CON SED (n=26), ETOH SED (n=27), CON EX (n=28), ETOH EX (n=25). Exercise (EX) mice had running wheel access from ZT13-15, while sedentary mice (SED) remained in their home cage. All mice were fed either a control (CON) or alcohol (ETOH)-containing liquid diet. Grip strength and body composition was measured before and after the interventions. After 6 weeks, muscle was collected every 4hrs and RT-PCR, Western blotting, and citrate synthase activity assay were performed in gastrocnemius. Plantaris muscle was used to measure cross sectional area and percentage of fiber type. RESULTS: Transcription of Bmal1, Per1, and Per2 was disrupted in ETOH SED vs. CON SED, while core clock mRNA expression was unaltered in ETOH EX compared to ETOH SED. CON EX phase shifted Bmal1 and Per1 mRNA compared to CON SED. While ETOH SED phase delayed peak nuclear protein expression of MYOD1 and DBP compared to CON SED, CON EX phase advanced peak expression of both proteins and ETOH EX phase advanced peak DBP nuclear expression. While REVERBa and BMAL1 circadian nuclear expression was unaltered, However, overall BMAL1 nuclear expression was increased in ETOH EX compared to ETOH SED. Alcohol blunted the hypertrophic response to exercise in the gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soleus muscles, and overall lean mass and blunted the exercise induced increase in forelimb grip strength. Citrate synthase activity was increased with exercise training in control and EtOH mice, while Complex I-V mitochondrial protein content and Cytochrome C and COXIV protein expression was increased with exercise. The exercise-induced increase in Pcg1a mRNA was impaired with alcohol, and mRNA expression of Opa1, Mfn1, and Drp1 were significantly correlated with average daily running distance, regardless of diet. The mitophagy marker BECLIN was also increased with exercise. CONCLUSION: This data suggests that scheduled voluntary wheel running may be unable to protect the muscle clock against alcohol-induced disruption and that alcohol partially blunts skeletal muscle adaptations to exercise training.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Student Perceptions of Criminal Justice: Does Criminal Justice-Related Curriculum Make a Difference?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Criminal justice education, justice, juvenile perceptions

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This qualitative and exploratory study sought to better understand how adolescent high school students form perceptions and opinions of the criminal justice system (CJS). Nine freshmen and nine seniors enrolled in a criminal justice magnet program in Florida were interviewed (separately). They were asked to gauge their level of trust in the CJS and to discuss which factors (i.e. personal experience, vicarious experiences expressed by friends & family, school curriculum, and news & social media) influenced their perceptions and opinions of the CJS the most. Additionally, senior participants were also asked to reflect on their time in the criminal justice magnet and to explain if/how the curriculum influenced their perceptions of the CJS. While some students indicated that personal experience, news and social media, and school curriculum influenced their opinions of the CJS, the most frequent response was vicarious experiences shared by friends and family. Furthermore, all senior participants stated they enjoyed their time in the magnet program and believed they could apply what they learned to their future career and educational goals. Most of the student participants expressed interest in legal, forensic, and social work-related occupations. Only 5 students anticipated pursuing careers in law enforcement; three of those five specified interest in federal law enforcement.

DISS_description.DISS_title: POLICING THE CAMPUS RAINBOW: THE ROLE OF CAMPUS LAW ENFORCEMENT IN THE PERCEPTIONS AND EXPERIENCES OF LGBTQ+ STUDENTS’ SAFETY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In a qualitative case study utilizing student focus groups, individual student interviews, individual interviews with the Chief of Police, and document analysis of annual campus safety guides and police websites, this study explored the perceptions and experiences that LGBTQ+ students had of their campus police agency at a large public research institution. With a total of 18 participants, all identifying within the LGBTQ+ student population, the study found that students are unaware of their campus police agency’s positionality on LGBTQ+ and have experienced discrimination from their agency based on their gender expression. Further findings showcased that the campus police agency wants to better their relationship with LGBTQ+ students and is willing to collaborate with minorized student groups to ensure the effectiveness of their community policing model.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PARENTAL CONTACT AND ITS RELATIONSHIP WITH ENGLISH TO SPEAKERS OF OTHER LANGUAGES (ESOL) STUDENTS’ ATTENDANCE AND ACHIEVEMENT

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This quantitative research study investigates the relationship between home-school communication and its connection with student attendance and the relationship between ESOL students’ attendance and academic achievement, focusing specifically on ESOL students at Northend High School (pseudonym) in the Henry William’s County Public Schools (HWCPS) (pseudonym), in the state of Maryland. From this focus, two research questions (RQs) emerged. The first is “What is the relationship between parental communication and ESOL students’ attendance in ESOL English classes at NHS?” The second is “What is the relationship between ESOL students’ attendance and achievement in their ESOL English classes at NHS?” To answer RQ 1, data on parental contact frequency and student attendance from quarter one to quarter four for the 2021-2022 school year in students' ESOL English classes were collected. To answer RQ 2, data on the number of absences of ESOL students in ESOL English classes and their quarterly grades in their ESOL English classes for the 2021-2022 school year were collected. The findings from previous research (Wilder, 2013; Benner et al., 2016; Rivera & Lavan, 2012; Day & Dotterer, 2018; Batalova et al., 2021; Roby, 2004; London et al., 2016) and the findings from the current research align. This study reveals that for RQ 1, the results are mixed. The relationship between parental contact and absenteeism in ESOL classes at NHS is strongest in quarters one and three and weakest in quarters two and four throughout the year. This study reveals that for RQ 2, student attendance is a significant variable when looking at student achievement.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Log-Profile Analysis of the Near-Surface Layer and Air-Sea Turbulent Fluxes in Hurricanes using Dropsondes

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: dropsondes, fluxes, hurricane, log-layer, MOS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Vertical profiles of wind, potential temperature, and humidity within hurricanes are shown to exhibit approximately log-linear behavior within the near-surface layer and can therefore be used to estimate log-profile parameters in such an environment. We analyze data collected from individual dropsondes in an attempt to better understand the near-surface values of wind, potential temperature, and humidity. This analysis has the advantage of simultaneously fitting all three non-neutral profiles via a Python-based minimization code. Several of these fitting parameters can be combined to estimate surface fluxes of momentum, sensible heat, and latent heat within tropical cyclones. Several strengths and weaknesses of this method will be discussed. Vertical offsets of the profiles have been observed, which could be due to waves or sea spray pushing them upward, or due to an error in the recorded surface level from the dropsonde. Our methodology accounts for these offsets through a displacement height for each profile. While still providing a very good fit to the observations, the log-profile parameters can be sensitive to displacement height error in a manner that impacts our estimation of fluxes. In addition, some assumptions are made regarding surface values for each of the profiles. In terms of a fit to the profiles, the errors in surface values are largely compensated for by the errors in roughness length and have no impact on the friction velocity (or similar terms) and fluxes. The errors in roughness length are exponentially related to the errors in the surface values, which in some cases results in extremely large roughness lengths. Despite the weaknesses, our methods are able to produce near-surface estimates and flux estimates within a certain range of uncertainty that is determined from the observed profiles. These uncertainties can theoretically be reduced in two ways: improved estimates of the surface values for current and temperature, and improved accuracy of the near-surface heights of dropsondes. Examples of the profiles, fluxes, and the above-mentioned problems will be presented.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A Cross-Cultural Analysis of Impulsive and Compulsive Buying Among Chinese, Indians and American Consumers

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Compulsive Buying, Consumer behaviors, Cross-Cultural Analysis, Impulsive Buying

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation examines the relationships between cultural dimensions and impulsive buying (IB) and compulsive buying (CB) behaviors in the US, China, and India. It systematically tests Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory's individual level of predicting power on IB and CB, compares the predicting level of Hofstede's cultural dimensions on IB and CB in the three countries, and explores the associations between impulsive buying and compulsive buying in cross-cultural contexts. The study found that cultural dimensions had different associations with IB and CB across the three countries, with masculinity, uncertainty avoidance, and indulgence being the most important predictors for IB and CB in the US, India, and China, respectively. Additionally, the study found that impulsive buying was associated with compulsive buying in all three countries. The findings highlight the importance of understanding cultural factors in driving these behaviors and provide a better understanding of IB and CB in cross-cultural context.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Scalable Learning with Probabilistic PCA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: catastrophic forgetting, class incremental learning, large scale learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Deep neural networks have drawn much attention due to their success in various vision tasks. Incremtnal Leaning is a paradigm where instances from new object classes are added sequentially.The traditional training scheme causes a problem called catastrophic forgetting where model the updated model forgets the old classes and focuses only on the new classes.In the second chapter, we propose a frame work called incremental PPCA for class incremental learningIncrementl PPCA uses a self-supervised pretrained feature extractor to obtain meaningful features and trains Probabilistic PCA models on the extracted features for each class separately. The Mahalanobis distance is used to obtain the classification result, and an equivalent equation is derived to make the approach computationally affordable.In the third chapter,Experiments on standard and large datasets show that the proposed approach outperforms existing state of the art incremental learning methods by a large margin. The fact that the model is trained on each class separately makes it applicable to training on very large datasets such as the whole ImageNet with more than 10,000 classes.

neural network classifiers don't exploit semantic relations between image classes. Inspired by our understanding of the human hierarchical cognition models, we propose a framework called Hierarchical PPCA for image classification in the fourth chapter. The framework uses probabilistic PCA models as basic classification units and adopts a modified k-means clustering to group the image classes into a smaller number of super-classes. During classification, Hierarchical PPCA assigns a sample to a small number of most likely super-classes, and restricts the image classification to the image classes corresponding to these super-classes. In the fifth chapter,experiments on three standard datasets ImageNet-100, ImageNet-1k and ImageNet-10k indicate the hierarchical classifier can achieve the same or superior accuracy with a 4-16 times speedup compared to a standard classifier.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A Demographic Study of Composers Studied in the Graduate Choral Literature Curriculum

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Choral Composers, Choral Literature, music curriculum

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to investigate the race, gender, and historical periods of composers included in syllabi for graduate choral literature courses in the southern region of the United States. The participants (N = 11) in this study were collegiate choral conductors teaching graduate choral literature courses at public/private colleges and universities. After analyzing the syllabi collected from the participants, the researcher extracted composers information from each syllabi including race, gender, and historical periods into a data collection sheet created by the researcher. The results indicated that White male composers from the Modern era are most frequently studied in graduate choral literature courses. The results also indicated that composers of color and women composers are significantly underrepresented in graduate choral literature curricula in the South. These findings suggest that a reform may be needed in graduate choral literature curricula to ensure more composers of color and women composers’ history and compositions are studied in graduate choral literature courses.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE PEDAGOGY, CAREER, AND INFLUENCE OF DR. STEPHEN M. WOLFINBARGER

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Dr. Steve Wolfinbarger, professor of music at Western Michigan University, has had an incredible impact on trombone pedagogy over the course of his more than forty-year career. His students play in premier ensembles and teach at over twenty-five colleges and universities domestically and abroad.
