His teaching has been recognized several times on a local and national stage, including citations from Western Michigan University in 2009, 2010, and 2014, as well as the 2013 Michigan Professor of the Year Award.Wolfinbarger has also been highly involved in the International Trombone Association and International Trombone Festival, helping to shape both into the organizations we see today. He hosted the 1990 International Trombone Workshop, served as president of the ITA from 1994-1996, and continues to serve on numerous committees and boards. The significance of his contributions to the trombone community has been recognized in two of the most prestigious awards given by the International Trombone Association, the ITA Award in 2009 and the Kenneth Hanlon Award in 2019. The bulk of research for this document was done through personal interviews with Dr. Wolfinbarger and correspondence with his former students and professional contacts. The goal of this research is to provide future performers and educators with a better understanding of Wolfinbarger’s pedagogical philosophies and techniques, as well as the extent of his influence in the trombone world.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Polarization and Covering on Sets of low Smoothness: Studying Short Range Repulsive Points by Asymptotic Behavior

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Analysis, Geometric Measure Theory, Potential Theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: One of the enduring problems over the last century has been the configurations of points which exhibit repulsive type behavior, such as particles of the same charge e.g. electrons, and determining which configurations would these points settle towards to minimize their collective energy when restricted to some compact domain. This problem is known as Thompson’s Problem and is named so for his model of the atom and has proven to be difficult to solve for general configurations of n- points, excluding a few exceptional cases of the vertices of the regular platonic solids. Recent work has been to study the asymptotic behavior of increasing the number of points in the configuration and studying how this affects the growth of the energy of these configurations. A major result in this area is attributed to Hardin and Saff which slightly generalizes to compact manifolds and is aptly named the Poppy Seed Bagel Theorem. We extend this result in a sharp sense and show that for highly non-smooth sets a similar result can be obtained.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Structure Revealed in Randomly Interacting Boson Ground States

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Bosons play an important role in the study of emergent phenomena, such as the appearance of effective degrees of freedom, symmetries, and phase transitions. In this work, we use an ensemble of Hamiltonians with two-body interactions with matrix elements randomly chosen from a normal distribution, to explore the behavior of the ground states of systems of identical bosons of spin $\ell$. We especially focus on the predominance of spin 0 (or a single boson spin $\ell$) ground states for an even (or odd) number of bosons. We find that the structure of bosonic ground state wavefunctions are not random, instead preferring to be arranged into condensates of clusters.

DISS_description.DISS_title: HOW PREDICTIVE VALIDITY IMPACTS CLASSIFICATION ACCURACY AND PREDICTIVE POWER ACROSS SCREENING APPROACHES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Screening benefits both individuals and systems, enabling early identification of treatable conditions at scale. In education, schools use a variety of assessments and approaches to screen for risk of dyslexia or reading difficulties, and these vary in terms of technical adequacy and ease of administration. Screening assessments are commonly evaluated in terms of classification accuracy, with ideal assessments having at least a sensitivity of .90 and a specificity of .80. A recent study demonstrated that the correlation between a screening assessment and criterion outcome assessment can be used in combination with the base rate of the target condition to derive classification accuracy without actually applying the assessment to a sample. This study demonstrated that a univariate (single indicator) screening assessment could not achieve ideal classification accuracy unless the screener-outcome correlation was at or above .85. Because this level of predictive validity is unrealistically high for a univariate screener, the present study used a series of simulations to test how adding an additional indicator affects the screener-outcome correlation needed to achieve ideal classification accuracy, and compares this threshold across screening approaches (e.g., single-timepoint versus gated screening). Results showed that one- and two-indicator screening approaches using cut-points to assign risk can almost never achieve ideal classification accuracy as commonly defined, particularly when the base rate in the sample is low. Further, the specific approach used to assign risk affected classification accuracy and predictive power. Implications for the recommendations given to schools regarding universal screening and future directions for research are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: What if the Monster Sings? Caliban's Humanity and Monstrosity Musically Negotiated in Adapations of Shakespeare's The Tempest

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Caliban, Listening, Monster studies, Opera, Shakespeare, The Tempest

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Shakespeare’s The Tempest is one of his most musical plays, and the monster Caliban is an inherently musical monster. He demonstrates musical skills and affinities, and his speech “Be not affeard” from Act 3, Scene 2, is one of Shakespeare’s most sonically evocative speeches. Yet Caliban’s speech seems uncharacteristic, because elsewhere Caliban is portrayed as grotesque. As a result of the play’s musical sensibilities, many composers have set the play as opera or concert works. Interrogation of the ways in which interpreters represent Caliban in these adaptations, particularly regarding his “Be not affeard” speech, provide a revealing window on cultural history. This study considers musical adaptations chronologically from the seventeenth century to the present, reading Caliban as a cultural text. It explores the cultural and epistemological contexts of these works and analyzes them through the lenses of dramaturgy and musical style.

The inconsistencies in the monster’s description leave openings for interpreters to inflect the character in any number of directions. In the eighteenth century he is fish-like. In the nineteenth century he is a caricature of the noble savage or the missing link in the human evolutionary chain. In the twentieth century he stands in as a representative of any number of oppressed people groups. The musical styles that represent Caliban run the gamut from stylized grunts or growls to virtuosic vocal lines.

Despite the sonically evocative language of Caliban’s speech, few composers set his remarkable speech about the island at all, and even fewer set it as a discrete aria in its original affect. Examination of musical adaptations of The Tempest shows that the impetus to leave out the speech, or to invert its affect, usually stems from discomfort with portraying the monster in a sympathetic way, because a vulnerable monster would undermine or threaten the stability of cultural values. In the Enlightenment, the predilection for binaries of opposites and dichotomous worldviews necessitated that Caliban be unequivocally malevolent. Nineteenth-century adaptations situated him under the archetype of the noble savage, reading his musical affinities as an index for the presence of a redeemable soul. The advent of postcolonial literary criticism in the mid-twentieth century sparked altogether more sympathetic readings of Caliban. The influence of these readings led composers to set Caliban’s speech as his aria, unrestrained in its ability to reveal the character’s interiority and vulnerability.

This dissertation thus situates Caliban as a revealing interpretive window onto cultural history, “listening” to him by reading him as culture and interpreting his meaning. More than other monsters, Caliban has a rich body of music composed for and around him, and listening to the performance of this music is another more phenomenological way to understand Caliban. Listening to the monster sing makes palpable his interiority and vulnerability and provides a way to know and feel Caliban’s emotional worlds.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Middle school teachers' perceptions of the effectiveness and relevance of mandated professional development

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: collaboration, content-focus, effectiveness, professional development, relevance, teachers

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Educators across the U.S. participate in professional development (PD) to improve their teaching competencies. Numerous legislatures have mandated PD to develop highly qualified teachers; however, literature on PD has shown that teachers feel PD does not meet their needs. With consideration for the diverse needs of teachers, in this study I sought to understand middle school teachers’ perceptions in one public school district in Florida regarding the effectiveness and relevance of mandated PD during school improvement time. Using an explanatory sequential mixed methods design, I collected data through an electronic questionnaire (n =21) and interviews (n = 7) to answer the question: What are middle school teachers’ perceptions of the effectiveness and relevance of district-mandated PD? The questionnaire results indicated teachers’ felt PD is effective when it focuses on content, is collaborative, and is coherent. Furthermore, teachers described PD that was applicable to the classroom and aligned to the needs of their school and students was relevant. I used interviews to explain these results further and found that content focus was lacking due to an emphasis on PD related to testing. Additionally, teachers explained that collaboration with teachers both in and outside of the content area they teach is effective. In contrast, the confusion teachers had regarding the planning of topics and PD led to them longing for coherence. After triangulating the data, I found teachers explained application as the ability to immediately use the training or resource without having to adapt it themselves. Furthermore, teachers elaborated that when PD is led by someone who has been in the classroom, understands their school, or teaches the same subject as them, they find it relevant. Teachers also shared that PD was focused on testing when it should be focused on topics related to content or student behaviors that have resulted from COVID-19. Findings from this study will benefit future educators and district personnel as they prepare for upcoming PD opportunities to address the needs of teachers within their district.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DYNAMICS OF A CELLULAR AUTOMATA MODEL AND ITS POSSIBLE APPLICATION TO REPLICATING CONVECTIVE BEHAVIOR

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Moist convection in the tropics often evolves from randomly scattered cells to organized structures varying across different spatial and temporal scales such as mesoscale convective systems (MCS), easterly waves, or the MJO. Scientists have begun implementing cellular automata (CA) and Conway’s Game of Life in modeling convection because of its similar evolution from a random state to a self-organizes state that tropical convection undergoes. Rules from the Game of Life are implemented in a CA model coupled to an energy reservoir in which an event forms if the energy reservoir in a grid cell exceeds a designated minimum threshold similar to CAPE. Events then consumes the background energy, and the instability once again builds up from the designated generation rate. This project’s main task is assessing the quantitative aspects such as number of events,environment instability, periodicity, and the qualitative behavior of events, visual and metric spatial organization of events in equilibirum, by experimenting with model parameters: instability generation, environment adjustment, neighboring cell influence, and cell persistence. The secondary task of the project is to evaluate the skill of the model to compare and contrast events in the CA model to idealized tropical convection in radiative-convective equilibirum (RCE ). Individually, energy generation and environment adjustment were found to have positive and negative contribution to quantity of events, and all four parameters affected environment instability in the model; multi-parameter sensitivity showed non-linear characteristics for events and instability. High rates of environment adjustment, low rates of instability generation, and moderate values of neighboring cell influence had the greatest qualitative response to event organization. This model was able to replicate some aspects of atmospheric convective behavior and acquire spatial organization, but the degree of organization and change with organization in time did not match the behavior of atmospheric convection.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Appraisals of Crime and Control Agents

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Crime Appraisals, Critical Criminology, Intersectionality, LGBTQ

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In a 2014 essay on “Queering Criminology,” Jordan B. Woods reflects on the wholesale failure of academic criminology to incorporate the unique experiences of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer (LGBTQ) people into the larger scope of critical scholarship (Woods, 2014). The absence of this inclusion from criminological literature and criminal justice theorizing – which remains too narrow – prevents a better understanding of and response to the needs of LGBTQ people to improve their experiences in the justice system. While the volume of intersectional literature has grown in that time, existing deficits and a demand for deeper conceptual development means that filling the scholarship vacuum continues to be relevant. A lack of data on LGBTQ people constrains our understanding of the ways in which identities may influence attitudes, beliefs, and norms around the effects of crime and the institutions used to control it.

This dissertation fills a gap in contemporary literature by aiming to strengthen the state of queer criminology and an understanding of intersectional identity on the outcomes of crime. Specifically, the following research uses cross-sectional data (n = 405) from a sample of urban respondents in New Orleans, Louisiana to quantitatively assess how intersections of identity influences one's: (1) fear of crime (FOC); and (2) law enforcement attitudes (LEA). Sexual and gender identity is disaggregated to tease out potential mediating and moderating effects on both outcomes, and the interlocking intersections between sex, sexual and gender-identity, and race are added to assess their roles in predicting FOC and LEA. Results show that there is a direct effect between some intersectional identities and FOC – particularly among those who identity as female – but these effects drop out with the inclusion of additional covariates. The data show an indirect association between some intersectional identities and LEA via FOC. They also show that attitudes regarding police procedural fairness are associated with LEA. This study may provide conditional support for a vulnerability thesis to explain variation in both FOC and LEA.

DISS_description.DISS_title: How Have Indigenous Mound Sites Affected the Biodiversity of the Atchafalaya River Basin?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: climate, historical ecology, NDVI

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ABSTRACT

The goal of this research is to investigate whether mound and shell midden archaeological sites in the Atchafalaya River Basin region have influenced the biodiversity and vegetative health of the surrounding environment. The general approach utilized a LiDAR Digital Elevation Model, Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), Louisiana Division of Archaeology Master Site File, and National Agriculture Imagery Program (NAIP) multi-spectral imagery datasets to construct a chronology of vegetation changes at mound sites in the Atchafalaya River Basin. The significance of these sites will be examined through the lens of Cultural-Ecosystem Resilience, wherein a system of cultural and natural forces works to promote community stability (Mehta and Chamberlain 2022). The potential ecological benefits of mounds in terms of increased biodiversity and resistance to erosion will also be explored. The methods used in this research are influenced by the work done at the Adams Bay site (16PL8) to examine the biodiversity effects of mounds (Mehta 2023).

Five different mound sites were selected to meet the following criteria: 1) Mound area covered in vegetation, 2) Mound surrounded by comparable type and density of vegetation, 3) Mound is recorded in the Louisiana Cultural Resources Map, 4) Located in the Atchafalaya River Basin. Mound locations from the Cultural Resources Map were then verified with a Digital Elevation Model of the area. Multispectral imagery from NAIP flights was downloaded and used to calculate NDVI for each site across a ten-year span of time. Vegetation growing on top of the mound sites on average outperformed nearby vegetation in the majority of cases, using NDVI values as a proxy for vegetative health and density. Analysis of NDVI value distribution at mound sites showed a clustering effect in the higher range associated with dense vegetation and high levels of chlorophyll. A significant drop in NDVI values at all sites was observed in 2017, possibly attributable to the previous year’s devastating “no-name storm” that caused extensive flooding across the region. The methodology employed seems suitable for site discovery or long-term monitoring of archaeological resources in highly vegetated areas.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INVESTIGATING DISTANT SOCCER FANS’ PERCEPTIONS OF SPORTS RIVALRY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: distant fans, sports rivalry

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Rivalry is omnipresent in sports given the nature of competition in sports. Sports fans likely can easily and quickly name a few rivalries from a variety of sports at either the professional or collegiate level, such as El Classico between Barcelona and Real Madrid. The long history of sports rivalry, the high exposure and rich stories produced by the sports media, the human and financial resources invested in rivalry games, and the frequent appearance of rivalries in sports fans’ discussions, all highlight the importance of sports rivalry. The purpose of this study is to explore distant fans’ perceptions of sports rivalry as a phenomenon with three major topics: (1) distant fans’ perceptions of sports rivalry, (2) the antecedents contributing to the perceived sports rivalry of distant fans, and (3) distant fans’ feelings of Schadenfreude, as well as the differences regarding these three topics toward the top and the secondary rival teams. This study will also include an examination of the role of team identification in association with the primary research topics.The current study utilized online questionnaires to gather data among distant fans of Liverpool FC from the United States, South Korea, China, Malaysia, and Singapore. Convenience sampling was used and questionnaires were distributed through the Official Liverpool Supporters Clubs from the listed countries. The information collected was analyzed using R-Studio and SPSS. Frequency analyses were conducted for the demographic questions and major research questions. Additionally, a qualitative analysis of distant fans’ socializing agents and influencing factors was provided. The assessment of reliability and the assumptions were checked before testing the hypotheses. The hypotheses examining the differences between the top and secondary rivals, as well as between the high and moderate identification fans, were tested by MANCOVA and ACNOVA. The association between team identification and rivalry perceptions as well as Schadenfreude were tested by simple linear regression and weighted regression. The key findings of the current study were three folds. Firstly, distant fans were likely to identify mass media as the socializing agents introducing them to their favorite sports team, including television, print media, social media, and Esports. Players, specific games, and team spirit were frequently mentioned when distant fans talked about the factors influencing them to become a fan. Secondly, in line with prior research, distant fans would not like to support the rivals when playing against a third party and had strong sense of satisfaction when their favorite team winning a direct game against the rivals. Highly identified distant fans were inclined to have stronger negative perceptions and feelings Schadenfreude against the rivals than fans with lower team identification. Thirdly, inconsistent with previous findings, distant fans did not perceive differently towards the top and secondary rivals nor have different levels of feelings of Schadenfreude. Distant fans perceived greater importance in relative dominance, defining moments, competition for personnel, and unfairness, while considered geography and cultural similarity least important in shaping the perceived rivalries.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Duoethnography: Exploring the Lived Experiences of Two Malaysian Music Therapy Students in the United States

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: diversity, duoethnography, education, international students, Malaysia, music therapy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Music therapy as a field has strived to embrace multiculturalism within education and practice. Over hundreds of thousands come to the United States in pursuit of higher education every year. For decades, these international scholars face many academic and non-academic challenges during their time away from home. Yet, many of these challenges remain relevant today. The purpose of this duoethnographic study was to explore the experiences of two international students who pursued music therapy education and training in the United States of America. The study describes the challenges faced and resources used, as well as provide perception and insights during their music therapy education and training. The participants were two Malaysian students who had received their music therapy education approximately 10 years apart. Both participants had two sessions of conversations, each lasting around one hour and a half. Data were derived from these conversations and categorized into themes and sub-themes, along with a brief transcription of the conversation accordingly. Themes and sub-themes that emerged are (1) Non-academic and academic challenges, (2) Tapping into available resources, (3) Conductive environment for growth, (4) Personal growth, (5) Finding a new ground between Eastern and Western values, (6) Gratitude, and (6) Hindsight. The study allowed participants an opportunity to verbally process their experiences and provide perspectives. While there is much effort put forward by music therapy organizations in developing cultural sensitivity within education and training, this study hopes to encourage further progression in cultural diversity, add insights into the direction of the cultural sensitivity within the field of music therapy, and contribute to the development of a diverse and resilient field.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Experience Asia: The Festivalization of Musicultures in Tallahassee

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Ethnomusicology, Festivalization, Panethnicity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This project examines how Asian cultural organizations in the United States represent and advocate for the preservation, development, and public presentation of Asian culture through festivals and outreach programs that often involve music, dance, cuisine, and exhibitions. Using the Asian Coalition of Tallahassee (ACT) as my case study, I argue that ACT music and dance events cultivate a collective sense of both particular and more broad-based cultural identities among Chinese, Filipino, Indian, Japanese, and other Asian-identifying groups in Tallahassee. In pursuing this line of argument, I apply theories of festivalization to show how cultural festivals serve to leverage political activism for Asian empowerment in the United States.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY OF WORKS FOR THE CLARINET BY ERNESTO CAVALLINI

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise examines Ernesto Cavallini’s published compositions for clarinet that are currently available to the public. This document is meant to serve as a resource for clarinetists, educators, and researchers who are interested in becoming more familiar with the works of Cavallini. It is comprised of a brief history of Ernesto Cavallini; an annotated bibliography of selected compositions that includes information about the title, meter, instrumentation, range of clarinet, structure, duration, measures, publishers, arrangements, recordings, level of difficulty; a brief description of the piece; a conclusion; and appendices listing the thirty caprices, all works written for clarinet, and information about publishers of this music.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Longleaf pine (Pinus palustris) growth and population dynamics under climate change: A dendroecological investigation across unique natural communities in FL, USA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: biogeography, dendrochronology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The longleaf pine (Pinus palustris) savanna is an endangered ecosystem within a global biodiversity hotspot. However, most studies of longleaf habitats have not considered the distinct structure and function of unique longleaf communities, which is critical for developing appropriate management strategies. Florida has 50% of the remaining habitat, where it occurs in unique community types that differ in their hydrology, species composition, and disturbance regimes. The structure and growth of longleaf pine in the different community types depends on the unique interactions between these abiotic and biotic components. The legacy of anthropogenic disturbance through logging, fragmentation, fire exclusion, and the rapidly changing climate have resulted in potentially novel dynamics for longleaf pine ecosystems. Identifying the drivers of tree growth and population dynamics can facilitate a better understanding of longleaf status and vulnerability to global change. In this dissertation, I explored and assessed how disturbances (fires and hurricanes) interact with species composition and climatic conditions to affect tree density, growth rates, and stand structure across community types in Florida.First, I assessed how differences in climate, fire, and species composition interact and relate to longleaf pine densities and growth rates in distinct communities. I used field surveys and tree cores to estimate stand structure and growth rates across community types. I used linear mixed-effects models to examine the effect of community type on longleaf pine density and growth rates and then used recursive partitioning and regression tree analyses to identify how climate, fire, and species composition affect density and growth rates. I found that stand structure and species composition were different across communities, whereas growth rates were not. Across communities, unique interactions between climate, fire, and species composition, resulted in differences in stand structure. In general, tree and grass stage densities were best predicted by species composition and fire rather than by climate within unique community types, whereas overall growth rates were best predicted by climate. I show that longleaf growth rates increased with higher temperatures, but this effect is reversed in dry conditions. Our research includes the southernmost extent of longleaf, and our results suggest that longleaf growth rates across its range will be more sensitive to current and future climate change than longleaf population density. Second, I used unique dendroecological methods to explore how climate and fire interact to affect annual tree growth. Traditional dendrochronological methods mask out individual variation by using stand level indices, and have a bias towards sampling resource limited trees, which is an effective strategy for climate reconstruction, but lacks an ecological focus. I present eight ecologically representative Florida longleaf pine chronologies and compare the strength of seasonwood and total ring width chronologies, finding that latewood growth had stronger climatic correlations, but not stronger crossdating. Then, I used correlation analyses to identify the primary climatic drivers of tree growth and found summer precipitation had a positive effect and summer temperature had a negative effect at a majority of sites, although there was no climatic variable at any season length with exact effects on tree growth across sites. Finally, I used linear mixed effects models to estimate how the climatic drivers interact with fire to affect individual tree growth. I identified unique effects from fire seasonality, with negative effects due to dormant season burning at 60% of sites. I found positive effects from fire in the previous year in 60% of sites. In many cases, fire reversed or neutralized the effect of climate, suggesting unique implications for management under climate change. By using ecologically representative samples, I show how climate and fire interact differently to affect tree growth and highlight variability in ecosystem function across communities and sites. Finally, I investigate immediate hurricane impacts to stand structure at four sites after experiencing an unprecedented Category 5 storm, which exemplifies the growing threats the longleaf pine ecosystem faces under anthropogenic climate change. I used variable-area transects and generalized linear mixed-effects models to estimate tree densities and logistic regression to estimate mortality by size class. I found at least 28% of the global total remaining extent of the longleaf pine ecosystem was affected in Florida alone. Mortality was highest in medium sized trees (30-45 cm dbh) and ranged from 4.6-15.4% at sites further from the storm center, but increased to 87.8% near the storm center. As the frequency and intensity of extreme events increases, management plans to mitigate the effects of climate change need to account for large-scale stochastic mortality events to preserve critical habitats. Even where protected, critical habitats are vulnerable to the effects of climate change.

DISS_description.DISS_title: STATISTICAL ANALYSIS ON REPRESENTATION SPACES OF AFFINE LINES AND AFFINE PLANES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: affine lines, affine planes

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation contains two related parts. The first part focuses on affine lines, and the second part is about affine planes. In the first part, it develops tools for statistical analysis on spaces of affine lines. Motivated by the problem of dimension reduction for high-dimensional dynamic data, it develops a natural mathematical representation of affine lines, endowed with a convenient Riemannian structure for computing basic quantities such as geodesics, sample means, and tangent PCA. It adapts recent works for constructing Be ́zier curves on Riemannian manifolds to this representation space and develops a tool for fitting smooth trajectories in the space of affine lines. Finally, it provides techniques to compare such trajectories resulting from different measurements in a manner that is invariant to the parameterizations of these trajectories. These individual tools together form a comprehensive toolbox for representing and analyzing large dynamical systems as low-dimensional objects. We demonstrate this toolbox using a number of examples from real and simulated data. In the second part, we apply a similar statistical analysis procedure on affine planes, such as developing a representation space of affine planes, equipping a Riemannian structure on it, and illustrating statistical analysis through some real and simulated datasets.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Evaluating the Complementariness of Transportation Research Journal Series (Parts A – F) with Topic Modeling

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bibliographic analysis, LDA, Text Classification, Topic Modeling

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The goal of this bibliographic study is to evaluate the complementariness of the Transportation Research Journal Series (Parts A – F) using various natural language processing techniques. First, large-scale bibliographic data, such as paper titles, abstracts, publication dates, and other metadata, were obtained from the Transportation Research International Documentation (TRID), the largest bibliographic database for transportation research. All papers published in Transportation Research (Parts A-F) between 2010 and 2020 were included. Second, after data preprocessing, a topic model, namely the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), was employed to discover latent transportation research topics and further reveal the correlation between transportation research topics and different parts of TR. Third, with topic distributions as features, various classification algorithms (e.g., logistic regression and support vector machines) were developed to predict the most probable TR part a given abstract is from. The accuracy of a classification algorithm could thus be used to assess the complementarity of the six parts of TR. One practical value of this study is that transportation researchers can better understand how various topics are aligned with the scopes of TR journals.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Love in Retrodiction: An Apocalyptic Comic Book

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Apocalyptic literature, Fiction, Novel

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Love in Retrodiction is a novel.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INCORPORATING OUT-OF-SAMPLE ERROR DIRECTLY INTO BAYESIAN HIERARCHICAL MODELS THROUGH CONSTRAINTS AND SUBSAMPLING

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The goal of this dissertation is to improve the predictive performance of a Bayesian hierarchicalstatistical model by incorporating an estimate of the expected out-of-sample error and extending this method for big data. In Chapter 2, we view the problem of prediction of a latent real-valued mean as a model selection problem, where the candidate models are all values in the parameter space for the mean of the data. Specifically, we select a subset of our Bayesian hierarchical statistical model’s parameter space with high predictive performance (as measured by a criterion). Explicitly, we truncate the joint support of the data and the parameter space of a given Bayesian hierarchical model to only include small values of the covariance penalized error (CPE) criterion. The CPE is a general expression that contains several information criteria as special cases. Simulation results show that as long as the truncated set does not have near-zero probability, we tend to obtain a lower mean squared error than Bayesian model averaging. Additional theoretical results are provided for the foundation for these observations. We apply our approach to a dataset consisting of American Community Survey (ACS) period estimates to illustrate that this perspective can lead to improvements of a single model. In Chapter 3, we use cross-validation as an estimate for CPE. Cross-validation is particularly useful in the big data context because subsampling the data into training and hold-out data naturally reduces the size of the training dataset. From this perspective, we propose a statistical model using the recently introduced data subset model and subset model formulation. Several theoretical results of our truncated data subset model have been presented. Additionally, we implement our approach to a CO2 dataset and compare the performance with different spatial predictors. Chapter 4 contains a discussion

DISS_description.DISS_title: “THE CAUSE OF LABOUR IS THE CAUSE OF IRELAND": TRANSNATIONAL REVOLUTIONARY INDUSTRIAL UNIONISM AND THE IRISH WORKING-CLASS MOVEMENT, 1896-1916

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation investigates the relationship between socialism, nationalism, and the working class in the British and American contexts during the early 20th century, with a particular emphasis on syndicalism and revolutionary industrial unionism. By examining the role of migration in the development of labor movements and the spread of ideas across the British world, this study highlights the significance of transnational networks in shaping the experiences of workers and the diffusion of syndicalist and industrial unionist ideologies. Key figures such as James Connolly and the Irish working-class movement are analyzed to explore the interplay between socialism, nationalism, and labor. The dissertation also delves into the role of unskilled workers in Dublin's labor movement and the impact of the Housing Question on the working class during the Irish Revolution. The study concludes with an examination of the events leading up to the Easter Rising, the role of the working class in the militarization of Irish society, and the broader implications of these developments on the labor movement. The findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the complexities of labor movements in the British and American contexts during the early 20th century and underscore the importance of transnational connections in the development and spread of labor-related ideologies.
